title: Unit test: suggest_all.go - Suggestion orchestration
description:
Create comprehensive unit tests for pkg/analysis/suggest_all.go

suggest_all.go orchestrates all suggestion types:
- Calls each individual suggester
- Combines and deduplicates results
- Applies global filtering and ranking

   - Test confidence threshold filtering
   - Test maximum suggestions limit

   - Small graph with known suggestion opportunities

   - Verify suggestions sorted by confidence
   - Verify deterministic ordering (stable sort)

- Create fixture graphs with known properties
- Test each suggester independently first
- Then test orchestration combinations
- Benchmark full suggestion pipeline

### Implementation Structure
```go
// pkg/export/wizard.go

type WizardConfig struct {
    IncludeClosed   bool
    Title           string
    Subtitle        string
    DeployTarget    string // "github", "cloudflare", "local"
    RepoName        string
    RepoPrivate     bool
    RepoDescription string
    OutputPath      string
}

func RunWizard(beadsPath string) error {
    config := &WizardConfig{}
    
    // Step 1: Collect export options
    if err := collectExportOptions(config); err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    // Step 2: Collect deployment target
    if err := collectDeployTarget(config); err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    // Step 3: Check prerequisites
    if err := checkPrerequisites(config); err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    // Step 4: Export bundle
    bundlePath, err := exportBundle(beadsPath, config)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    // Step 5: Preview
    if shouldPreview() {
        action := runPreview(bundlePath)
        if action == "quit" {
            return nil
        }
    }
    
    // Step 6: Deploy
    return deploy(bundlePath, config)
}
```

### Terminal UI
Use Go packages for nice TUI:
- `github.com/charmbracelet/huh` for forms (consistent with bubbletea)
- `github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss` for styling
- Or simpler: `bufio.Scanner` + ANSI colors

### State Persistence
Save wizard config for future runs:
```
~/.config/bv/pages-wizard.json
{
  "last_repo_name": "my-project-status",
  "last_deploy_target": "github",
  "include_closed": false
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] --pages flag launches wizard
- [ ] All steps work interactively
- [ ] Prerequisites check validates tools
- [ ] Preview server works with key controls
- [ ] GitHub deployment creates/updates repo
- [ ] Success message shows correct URLs
- [ ] Config saved for next run
- [ ] Ctrl+C cleanly exits at any step
- [ ] Works in non-TTY with sensible defaults

## Error Handling
- gh not installed: Offer to install (brew) or show manual instructions
- gh not authenticated: Run `gh auth login` inline
- Repo exists: Option to update or choose new name
- Network errors: Clear message with retry option

title: Agent Swarm Protocol: Multi-Agent Coordination
description:
Enable multiple AI agents to work on the same project without conflicts.

## INTEGRATION PRINCIPLES FOR AI AGENTS

### Problem This Solves
Without coordination, multiple agents (Claude Code, Cursor, Codex) will:
- Work on the same issues simultaneously
- Edit the same files causing merge conflicts
- Duplicate effort or produce conflicting changes

### How It Integrates With Existing Commands
This feature AUGMENTS existing commands, doesn't replace them:

1. **--robot-plan** will include a new field:
   ```json
   {
     "tracks": [...],
     "agent_claims": {
       "bv-42": {"agent": "claude-opus-1", "claimed_at": "...", "expires_at": "..."}
     },
     "available_for_claim": ["bv-43", "bv-44"]  // Excludes claimed work
   }
   ```

2. **--robot-priority** will filter out claimed items by default:
   ```json
   {
     "recommendations": [...],  // Only unclaimed items
     "claimed_by_others": 3     // How many filtered out
   }
   ```

### Self-Documenting Output Pattern
Every agent-related robot command MUST include an 'explanation' field:
```json
{
  "command": "--robot-agents",
  "result": {...},
  "explanation": {
    "what": "Shows all agents currently registered on this project",
    "when_to_use": "Before starting work to see who else is active",
    "action": "If you see other agents, use --robot-claim to reserve your work"
  }
}
```

### Claim Expiration
Claims auto-expire after 30 minutes of no heartbeat. This prevents orphaned claims from blocking work.

### File Hints Are Advisory
File reservation hints are NOT locks - they're signals to other agents. An agent seeing a conflict should:
1. Check if the other agent is still active (recent heartbeat)
2. If inactive > 30min, proceed with work
3. If active, choose different work or coordinate

Labels: [agent-swarm coordination]

title: Unified Triage Intelligence
description:
# Unified Triage Intelligence: The Mega Command

**This is THE primary entry point for AI agents using bv.**

## Vision

Instead of agents calling 5-10 different robot commands and mentally merging results, `--robot-triage` provides EVERYTHING an agent needs in ONE call:

- What should I work on? (recommendations)
- Are there fires to put out? (alerts)
- Who else is working? (team awareness)
- Will I conflict with anyone? (file conflicts)
- What's the project health? (stats, graph, labels)
- Any handoffs waiting for me? (collaboration)

## Design Principles

1. **One call = full context** - Agent calls triage once, has everything
2. **Critical first** - Alerts before recommendations
3. **Actionable throughout** - Every section says what to DO
4. **Self-documenting** - Output explains itself
5. **Team-aware** - Multi-agent coordination built-in
6. **Progressive detail** - Summaries by default, deep-dive commands available

## Output Structure (Priority Order)

```
1. meta           - Command info, timestamp, data hash
2. quick_ref      - One-line summary for fast parsing
3. alerts         - Critical issues FIRST (fires before features)
4. top_pick       - THE #1 recommendation with full reasoning
5. your_session   - Your claims, handoffs, context
6. team           - Other agents, conflicts, available tracks
7. recommendations- Next 5 items after top_pick
8. quick_wins     - Low-effort high-impact items
9. blockers       - Items that unblock the most work
10. project_health- Stats, graph health, label health, drift
11. suggestions   - Hygiene hints (missing deps, stale claims)
12. commands      - Exact commands for next steps
```

title: Implement unified scoring algorithm
description:
INCREMENTAL ENHANCEMENT on existing scoring

## What Already Exists (DO NOT DUPLICATE)
- `pkg/analysis/priority.go:ComputeImpactScores()` - composite scoring
- Existing weights: PageRank(30%), Betweenness(30%), BlockerRatio(20%), Staleness(10%), PriorityBoost(10%)
- `pkg/analysis/priority.go:ScoreBreakdown` - individual component tracking

## What This Adds (NEW VALUE)
TRIAGE-specific scoring that EXTENDS base scoring with:
1. Label health factor (from bv-99 labels view) - boost items in unhealthy labels
2. Agent claim factor (from bv-132) - reduce score for claimed items
3. Unblock impact factor - boost items that unblock many others
4. Quick-win factor - boost small items with high impact ratio

## Incremental Implementation (Graceful Degradation)

**Phase 1 (MVP):** Works with existing scoring only
```go
TriageScore = ComputeImpactScores() // 100% weight
```

**Phase 2 (Labels ready):** Add label health
```go
TriageScore = BaseScore*0.7 + LabelHealthBoost*0.15 + UnblockBoost*0.15
```

**Phase 3 (Agent Swarm ready):** Add claim penalty
```go
if claimedByOther { TriageScore *= 0.1 } // Heavily penalize claimed items
```

**Phase 4 (Attention scores ready):** Refine label factor
```go
// Replace simple label health with attention-weighted health
LabelHealthBoost = labelAttentionScore * 0.15
```

## Key Principle
Start simple, enhance incrementally. Never block triage on optional features.

## Output Format
```json
{
  "triage_scores": [{
    "issue_id": "bv-42",
    "base_score": 0.72,
    "triage_score": 0.85,
    "factors_applied": ["base", "label_health", "unblock"],
    "factors_pending": ["claim_penalty", "attention_score"]
  }]
}

title: Implement --robot-triage command
description:
# --robot-triage: The Mega Command (Incremental Implementation)

**THE primary entry point for AI agents. One call = everything available.**

## Key Design Principle: Graceful Degradation

The mega-command works with WHATEVER features are available. Sections are included only when their underlying systems are ready:

| Section | Requires | Phase |
|---------|----------|-------|
| meta, quick_ref | Nothing | 1 (MVP) |
| recommendations | ComputeImpactScores() | 1 (MVP) |
| project_health.counts | Basic stats | 1 (MVP) |
| project_health.graph | Analyzer | 1 (MVP) |
| alerts | Proactive Alerts (bv-135) | 2 |
| your_session, team | Agent Swarm (bv-132) | 2 |
| project_health.labels | Labels View (bv-99) | 2 |
| history_hints | History (bv-62) | 3 |
| suggestions | Smart Suggestions (bv-137) | 3 |

**Missing sections return `null` or are omitted entirely.**

## Phase 1 MVP Output (Works Today)

```json
{
  "meta": {"command": "--robot-triage", "generated_at": "...", "data_hash": "..."},
  "quick_ref": {
    "top_pick": "bv-43: Implement auth middleware",
    "actionable_items": 33,
    "status": "ready_to_work"
  },
  "alerts": null,
  "top_pick": {
    "bead_id": "bv-43",
    "title": "Implement auth middleware",
    "score": 94.2,
    "why": ["Highest impact score", "Unblocks 5 items"],
    "claim_command": "bv --robot-claim bv-43"
  },
  "your_session": null,
  "team": null,
  "recommendations": [...],
  "quick_wins": [...],
  "blockers_to_clear": [...],
  "project_health": {
    "counts": {"total": 169, "open": 131, "blocked": 12},
    "graph": {"cycles": 0, "density": 0.15, "health": "good"},
    "labels_attention": null,
    "drift": null
  },
  "suggestions": null,
  "commands": {"claim_top_pick": "bv --robot-claim bv-43", "see_full_plan": "bv --robot-plan"}
}
```

## Full Output (All Features Enabled)

[Previous full specification remains valid - all 12 sections populated]

## Implementation Approach

```go
func ComputeTriage(agentName string) TriageResult {
    result := TriageResult{
        Meta: buildMeta(),
    }
    
    // Phase 1: Always available
    result.Recommendations = computeRecommendations()
    result.TopPick = result.Recommendations[0]
    result.ProjectHealth.Counts = computeCounts()
    result.ProjectHealth.Graph = computeGraphHealth()
    result.QuickWins = findQuickWins()
    result.BlockersToClear = findBlockers()
    
    // Phase 2: If agent swarm available
    if agentSwarmEnabled() {
        result.YourSession = getSessionContext(agentName)
        result.Team = getTeamStatus()
    }
    
    // Phase 2: If alerts available  
    if alertsEnabled() {
        result.Alerts = getAlerts()
    }
    
    // Phase 2: If labels view available
    if labelsEnabled() {
        result.ProjectHealth.LabelsAttention = getLabelHealth()
    }
    
    // Phase 3: If history available
    if historyEnabled() {
        result.HistoryHints = getHistoryHints()
    }
    
    // Phase 3: If suggestions available
    if suggestionsEnabled() {
        result.Suggestions = getSuggestions()
    }
    
    result.QuickRef = buildQuickRef(result)
    result.Commands = buildCommands(result)
    
    return result
}
```

## Usage

```bash
bv --robot-triage                    # Full output (whatever is available)
bv --robot-triage --compact          # Minimal: quick_ref + top_pick + alerts
bv --robot-triage --agent=claude-1   # Include agent-specific context
```

## Companion Command

`bv --robot-next` - Returns ONLY top_pick (~10 lines). Same incremental approach.

title: Implement --robot-next command
description:
# --robot-next: The One-Answer Command

**For when you just need ONE thing to work on. No context, no analysis, just an answer.**

## Usage
```bash
bv --robot-next                    # What should I do next?
bv --robot-next --skip=bv-42       # Skip specific bead
bv --robot-next --agent=claude-1   # Respect agent claims
```

## Output (Minimal by Design)

```json
{
  "next": {
    "bead_id": "bv-43",
    "title": "Implement auth middleware",
    "score": 94.2,
    "why": "Unblocks 5 items, label needs attention",
    "claim": "bv --robot-claim bv-43"
  },
  "alerts": 2,
  "your_claims": 1
}
```

That's it. ~10 lines of JSON.

## When to Use

| Scenario | Use |
|----------|-----|
| Starting fresh session | `--robot-triage` (full context) |
| Mid-session, need quick direction | `--robot-next` |
| Polling frequently | `--robot-next` |
| First time on project | `--robot-triage` |
| Debugging/investigating | `--robot-triage` |

## Behavior

1. Computes full triage internally (same as --robot-triage)
2. Returns ONLY the top_pick + minimal metadata
3. Respects agent claims (excludes items claimed by others)
4. Excludes your own claims (you already have work)
5. Applies --skip filters

## Edge Cases

**No work available:**
```json
{
  "next": null,
  "reason": "all_claimed",
  "suggestion": "Wait for claims to release or help with bv-42 (claimed by cursor-agent)"
}
```

**Critical alerts pending:**
```json
{
  "next": {
    "bead_id": "bv-43",
    "title": "Implement auth middleware",
    "claim": "bv --robot-claim bv-43"
  },
  "alerts": 1,
  "alert_preview": "CRITICAL: Dependency cycle detected",
  "suggestion": "Run bv --robot-triage to see full alert details"
}
```

## Implementation

Internally calls the same triage computation as --robot-triage, then:
```go
func RobotNext(agentName string, skip []string) NextResult {
    full := ComputeTriage(agentName)
    
    if len(full.Alerts.Critical) > 0 {
        return NextResult{
            Next: full.TopPick,
            Alerts: len(full.Alerts.Critical) + len(full.Alerts.Warning),
            AlertPreview: full.Alerts.Critical[0].Message,
            Suggestion: "Run bv --robot-triage to see full alert details",
        }
    }
    
    return NextResult{
        Next: full.TopPick,
        Alerts: len(full.Alerts.Warning),
        YourClaims: len(full.YourSession.Claims),
    }
}
```

## Relationship to --robot-triage

```
--robot-triage  = Full meal (everything you need)
--robot-next    = Snack (just the answer)
```

Both compute the same underlying triage. --robot-next just returns less.

title: Auto-update mechanism with user confirmation
description:
Implement true auto-update for bv binary

## Current State
- Version check exists (notifies user when new version available)
- User must manually download and install

## Desired Behavior

### Interactive Mode
```
$ bv
New version available: v0.12.0 (current: v0.11.3)
Update now? [Y/n]: y
Downloading v0.12.0... done
Replacing binary... done  
Restarting... 
```

### Auto-Update Mode (opt-in)
```yaml
# .beads/config.yaml or ~/.config/bv/config.yaml
auto_update: true
auto_update_channel: stable  # stable | beta | nightly
```

When enabled, updates happen silently on startup (with brief notification).

### CLI Flags
```bash
bv --update              # Update now (interactive)
bv --update --yes        # Update now (non-interactive)
bv --check-update        # Just check, dont update
bv --set-auto-update     # Enable auto-updates
```

## Implementation Approach

1. **Download mechanism**
   - Fetch release info from GitHub API
   - Download appropriate binary for OS/arch
   - Verify checksum (SHA256)
   
2. **Safe replacement**
   - Download to temp location first
   - Verify binary runs (`bv --version`)
   - Atomic rename to replace current binary
   - Handle permission issues gracefully

3. **Rollback capability**
   - Keep previous version as `bv.backup`
   - `bv --rollback` to restore if issues

4. **Platform considerations**
   - Linux/macOS: Direct binary replacement
   - Windows: May need wrapper script for in-use binary
   - Homebrew users: Warn that brew manages updates

## Security Considerations
- Always verify checksums
- Download only from official GitHub releases
- Consider code signing for binaries
- Warn if running as root

## Edge Cases
- No internet connection: Skip gracefully
- Rate limited by GitHub API: Cache check results
- Binary in read-only location: Prompt for sudo or suggest manual update
- Running in CI: Never auto-update, just notify

title: Implement vim-style keyboard navigation and shortcuts
description:
# Vim-Style Keyboard Navigation

## Context
Power users expect keyboard-driven navigation. Implement vim-style shortcuts for efficient exploration.

## Keybindings

### Graph Navigation
| Key | Action |
|-----|--------|
| j/k | Move to next/prev node (by PageRank order) |
| h/l | Navigate dependency chain (predecessors/successors) |
| Enter | Focus/expand selected node |
| Esc | Deselect, exit focus mode |
| f | Focus mode (zoom to selection) |
| 0 | Reset zoom to fit all |

### Filtering
| Key | Action |
|-----|--------|
| / | Open search/filter |
| :o | Filter to open issues |
| :c | Filter to closed issues |
| :b | Filter to blocked issues |
| :p0-4 | Filter by priority |
| :l <name> | Filter by label |

### Actions
| Key | Action |
|-----|--------|
| w | What-if mode (click simulates close) |
| c | Toggle critical path |
| g | Toggle clustering/galaxy view |
| m | Toggle mini-map |
| ? | Show keyboard shortcuts help |

### Implementation
```javascript
document.addEventListener('keydown', (e) => {
    if (e.target.tagName === 'INPUT') return;
    
    switch (e.key) {
        case 'j': selectNextNode(); break;
        case 'k': selectPrevNode(); break;
        case 'h': navigateToPredecessor(); break;
        case 'l': navigateToSuccessor(); break;
        case 'Enter': focusSelectedNode(); break;
        case 'Escape': deselectAll(); break;
        case 'f': toggleFocusMode(); break;
        case '/': openSearch(); e.preventDefault(); break;
        case 'w': toggleWhatIfMode(); break;
        case 'c': toggleCriticalPath(); break;
        case '?': showShortcutsHelp(); break;
    }
});
```

## Visual Feedback
- Selected node: thick border, glow effect
- Navigation shows path taken
- Mode indicators in status bar

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All keybindings work
- [ ] Visual selection feedback
- [ ] Search modal opens on /
- [ ] Help modal shows shortcuts
- [ ] Works across views (graph, table, charts)
close_reason: Implemented vim-style keyboard navigation: / for search, ? for help modal, h/l for dependency chain navigation, o to open first issue. Added keyboard shortcuts help modal.

title: Light Mode Terminal: Low Color Contrast Makes Text Unreadable
description:
## Problem Statement

The bv color scheme is very hard to read on light terminal backgrounds. The 'dimmed' text (Subtext, Muted colors) is nearly invisible on white backgrounds, making the application unusable for users with light terminal themes.

## User Impact

**Severity: High (P1)**
- Effectively blocks users with light terminal themes
- Affects readability of secondary information (dimmed text, hints)
- Reported by @mikker in GitHub Issue #17

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `pkg/ui/theme.go:41-64`

The theme uses `lipgloss.AdaptiveColor` which provides Light/Dark values:

```go
Subtext: lipgloss.AdaptiveColor{Light: "#999999", Dark: "#BFBFBF"}
Muted:   lipgloss.AdaptiveColor{Light: "#888888", Dark: "#6272A4"}
```

The Light values are too light for white backgrounds:
- `#999999` on white = contrast ratio ~2.8:1 (WCAG AA requires 4.5:1 for normal text)
- `#888888` on white = contrast ratio ~3.5:1 (still fails WCAG AA)

While lipgloss attempts auto-detection of terminal background color, the chosen Light values are simply too faint regardless.

## Proposed Solution

### Fix 1: Improve Light mode color contrast

```go
// Improved light mode colors (WCAG AA compliant)
Subtext: lipgloss.AdaptiveColor{Light: "#666666", Dark: "#BFBFBF"} // ~6:1 contrast
Muted:   lipgloss.AdaptiveColor{Light: "#555555", Dark: "#6272A4"} // ~7:1 contrast
```

All colors need review:
- Primary: #7D56F4 on white = ~4.6:1 (barely passes)
- Secondary: #555555 is good
- Status colors need verification

### Fix 2 (Optional): Add explicit theme flag

```bash
bv --theme=light   # Force light mode colors
bv --theme=dark    # Force dark mode colors
bv --theme=auto    # Default: auto-detect (current behavior)
```

This helps when auto-detection fails or user preference differs.

## Color Audit Required

All AdaptiveColor values need contrast verification:

| Color | Current Light | Contrast | Suggested Light | New Contrast |
|-------|--------------|----------|-----------------|--------------|
| Subtext | #999999 | 2.8:1 âŒ | #666666 | 6:1 âœ“ |
| Muted | #888888 | 3.5:1 âŒ | #555555 | 7:1 âœ“ |
| Secondary | #555555 | 7:1 âœ“ | Keep | - |
| Open | #00A800 | 2.7:1 âŒ | #007700 | 4.6:1 âœ“ |
| Closed | #555555 | 7:1 âœ“ | Keep | - |
| Border | #DDDDDD | 1.4:1 âŒ | #AAAAAA | 2.3:1 (border OK) |

## Test Plan

1. Manual test on iTerm2 with Solarized Light theme
2. Manual test on macOS Terminal with default light theme
3. Verify all text elements are readable
4. Verify status colors are distinguishable
5. Consider adding screenshot tests

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All text readable on white terminal background
- [ ] Status colors visually distinguishable on light background
- [ ] Existing dark mode appearance unchanged
- [ ] Optional: --theme flag for explicit control
- [ ] No WCAG AA violations for text colors (4.5:1 minimum)

## References

- GitHub Issue #17: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/17
- WCAG Color Contrast Guidelines: https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/contrast-minimum.html
- lipgloss AdaptiveColor: https://github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss#adaptive-colors
close_reason: Improved light mode color contrast for WCAG AA compliance - darker Subtext, Muted, Open, InProgress, Feature, Task, Chore, and Border colors

title: openInEditor Uses Hardcoded Path Instead of Configured beadsPath
description:
## Problem Statement

The 'O' keybinding to open the beads file in editor fails when the file isn't named exactly `beads.jsonl`. The `openInEditor()` function hardcodes the path instead of using the `beadsPath` field already stored in the Model.

## User Impact

**Severity: High (P1)**
- Fails silently or shows error for projects using `issues.jsonl`
- beads upstream uses `issues.jsonl` as canonical, not `beads.jsonl`
- Reported by @qmx in GitHub PR #18

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `pkg/ui/model.go:2945-2955`

```go
func (m *Model) openInEditor() {
    cwd, err := os.Getwd()
    // ...
    beadsFile := filepath.Join(cwd, ".beads", "beads.jsonl")  // HARDCODED!
    if _, err := os.Stat(beadsFile); os.IsNotExist(err) {
        m.statusMsg = "No .beads/beads.jsonl file found"  // Wrong error message
        // ...
    }
}
```

The Model already has a `beadsPath` field (line 138) that's set during initialization and used for file watching. This function ignores it.

## Why This Matters

The beads project documentation (pre-commit hook) states:
> Stage all tracked JSONL files (issues.jsonl is canonical, beads.jsonl for backward compat)

So the hardcoded `beads.jsonl` path is wrong for the canonical case.

## Proposed Solution

```go
func (m *Model) openInEditor() {
    if m.beadsPath == "" {
        m.statusMsg = "No beads file configured"
        m.statusIsError = true
        return
    }

    if _, err := os.Stat(m.beadsPath); os.IsNotExist(err) {
        m.statusMsg = fmt.Sprintf("Beads file not found: %s", m.beadsPath)
        m.statusIsError = true
        return
    }
    
    // Continue with m.beadsPath instead of hardcoded path...
}
```

## Test Plan

1. Test: openInEditor with beadsPath set to issues.jsonl - should work
2. Test: openInEditor with beadsPath empty - should show "No beads file configured"
3. Test: openInEditor with beadsPath pointing to non-existent file - should show path in error
4. Manual test: 'O' key works for both beads.jsonl and issues.jsonl projects

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Uses m.beadsPath instead of hardcoded path
- [ ] Error messages include actual file path for debugging
- [ ] Works for issues.jsonl, beads.jsonl, and any other valid jsonl file
- [ ] Tests cover all error paths

## Dependencies

**Blocked by:** bv-mvvu (Data Integrity: Merge Artifact Files)
- The beadsPath value depends on correct file selection
- Fix the loader first, then this will use the correct path

## References

- GitHub PR #18: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/pull/18
- beads pre-commit hook documentation on canonical file names
close_reason: Fixed: openInEditor now uses m.beadsPath instead of hardcoded 'beads.jsonl'. Error messages now include actual file path. Build verified.

title: Port K-Shortest Paths and Parallel Cut analysis to Rust WASM
notes:
BUG FIX NEEDED: Current implementation stores only ONE predecessor per node (pred = vec![None; n]), so it can only reconstruct ONE path per endpoint. To get truly distinct k paths:

OPTION A (Simple): Find k distinct sinks by longest distance, reconstruct one path each. This gives k paths ending at different nodes.

For v1, Option A is acceptable since we want paths to k DIFFERENT high-priority issues. Document this limitation in the return type.

title: Toggleable Keyboard Shortcuts Sidebar
description:
## Feature Request

Add a toggleable sidebar panel that displays keyboard shortcuts while using the application. Unlike the current help overlay (which is modal and blocks interaction), this would be a persistent panel that can be shown/hidden while continuing to work.

## User Request

From @austinm911 in GitHub Issue #8:
> Not sure if anyone would find this helpful but there are a lot of shortcuts here so I am always using ? to view them (unable to scroll this view on Warp terminal). It would be nice to have a keyboard shortcuts panel that could be toggled on/off so we can see the rest of the panels.

## Why This Matters

bv has 60+ keyboard shortcuts across multiple contexts. Learning these shortcuts improves efficiency, but the current modal help overlay:
1. Blocks the main view while open
2. Cannot be scrolled on some terminals (separate bug: bv-43js)
3. Must be reopened each time you forget a shortcut

## Proposed Approaches

### Option A: Persistent Sidebar (Recommended)

A right-side panel that can be toggled on/off. Toggle with a key like F2 or Shift+?. Shows shortcuts organized by category, scrollable within the sidebar.

### Option B: Context-Sensitive Status Bar

Show relevant shortcuts in the footer based on current view/focus. Less intrusive but shows fewer shortcuts.

### Option C: Compact Floating Panel

A smaller overlay that does not cover the entire screen.

## Design Considerations

1. Width impact: Sidebar reduces main content width
2. Context awareness: Show shortcuts relevant to current view/focus
3. Persistence: Remember toggle state across sessions?
4. Customization: Allow users to choose which shortcuts to show?

## Priority Justification

P4 (Backlog) because:
- Nice-to-have, not critical functionality
- Help overlay serves the basic need (once scroll bug is fixed)
- Requires significant UI work
- Should implement after help overlay scroll (bv-43js)

## Dependencies

Blocked by: bv-43js (Help Overlay Scroll)
- Fix the existing help system first
- Learn from help scroll implementation patterns
- Sidebar might reuse scroll logic

## Test Plan

1. Toggle sidebar on/off with key
2. Layout adjusts correctly with sidebar
3. Shortcuts update based on context
4. Works in all views

## Acceptance Criteria

- Toggleable sidebar or alternative implementation
- Shows relevant keyboard shortcuts
- Does not block main interaction
- Scrollable if content exceeds height
- Adapts to terminal size
- Works across all views

## References

- GitHub Issue #8: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/8
- Related: bv-43js (help overlay scroll) - should fix first

title: Help Overlay Cannot Be Scrolled on Small Terminals
description:
## Problem Statement

The help overlay (triggered by '?' or F1) displays all keyboard shortcuts in a fixed box. On terminals smaller than the content height, the help content is cut off with no way to scroll and see the remaining shortcuts.

## User Impact

**Severity: Medium (P2)**
- Affects discoverability of keyboard shortcuts
- Particularly problematic on smaller screens or split terminal panes
- User @austinm911 mentioned this in GitHub Issue #8
- Identified during PR #16 review from @kraitsura

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `pkg/ui/model.go:1731-1889` (`renderHelpOverlay` function)

The function builds a string with all shortcuts and renders it in a fixed box:

```go
helpBox := t.Renderer.NewStyle().
    Border(lipgloss.RoundedBorder()).
    BorderForeground(t.Primary).
    Padding(1, 3).
    Render(helpContent)  // All content, no scroll

return lipgloss.Place(m.width, m.height-1, lipgloss.Center, lipgloss.Center, helpBox)
```

There's no scroll state, no key handlers for navigation, and no visual indicator of content overflow.

## Why This Matters

The help overlay shows 60+ lines of keyboard shortcuts across multiple sections:
- Navigation (9 items)
- Views (7 items)
- Graph View (4 items)
- Insights Panel (5 items)
- History View (7 items)
- Filters (5 items)
- General (7 items)

Even on a 40-line terminal, much of this content is hidden.

## Proposed Solution

### Add scroll support to help overlay

1. **Add scroll state to Model:**
   ```go
   helpScroll int // Current scroll offset for help overlay
   ```

2. **Handle navigation keys when help focused:**
   ```go
   case focusHelp:
       switch msg.String() {
       case "j", "down":
           m.helpScroll++
       case "k", "up":
           if m.helpScroll > 0 { m.helpScroll-- }
       case "ctrl+d":
           m.helpScroll += 10
       case "ctrl+u":
           m.helpScroll = max(0, m.helpScroll-10)
       case "home", "g":
           m.helpScroll = 0
       default:
           // Any other key dismisses help
           m.showHelp = false
           m.helpScroll = 0
       }
   ```

3. **Render visible portion with scroll indicator:**
   - Calculate visible lines based on terminal height
   - Clamp scroll position to valid range
   - Show scroll position indicator (e.g., scrollbar or percentage)

4. **Add navigation hint in help footer:**
   ```
   â†‘â†“ scroll â”‚ q close â”‚ â—â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ (scroll indicator)
   ```

## Design Considerations

1. **Fixed width rendering**: Prevent box resize as content scrolls
2. **Scroll indicator**: Show position in content (scrollbar or percentage)
3. **Graceful degradation**: On very small terminals, show most important shortcuts first
4. **Reset scroll on open**: Always start at top when reopening help

## Test Plan

1. Test: j/k keys scroll content up/down
2. Test: Ctrl+d/u for page navigation
3. Test: Home/g goes to top
4. Test: Any non-navigation key closes help
5. Test: Scroll resets to 0 on reopen
6. Test: Scroll indicator updates correctly
7. Manual test: Various terminal sizes

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Help overlay scrollable with j/k, arrows, Ctrl+d/u
- [ ] Visual scroll indicator shows position
- [ ] Non-navigation keys still dismiss help
- [ ] Scroll position resets when reopened
- [ ] Works correctly at edge cases (top/bottom of content)
- [ ] Fixed width prevents layout shift during scroll

## References

- GitHub PR #16: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/pull/16
- GitHub Issue #8: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/8 (related)
- Related: Help content is extensive and growing with each feature

func (p *PreviewServer) Start() error {
    mux := http.NewServeMux()
    
    // Static file server with no-cache
    fs := http.FileServer(http.Dir(p.bundlePath))
    mux.Handle("/", noCacheMiddleware(fs))
    
    p.server = &http.Server{

}

title: Impact Radar & Drift Alerts
description:
Detect significant changes in graph metrics and alert when structure degrades.

## Background & Motivation
Graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, cycles) can degrade over time without anyone noticing. A new cycle might be introduced, or a bottleneck might emerge. Proactive detection prevents issues from compounding.

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: Early warning when project health degrades
- For AI Agents: Validate changes before committing - 'did I introduce a cycle?'

## Technical Approach
1. Baseline storage (snapshot of metrics at a point in time)
2. Drift calculator (compare current to baseline)
3. Threshold configuration (when to alert)
4. CLI: --check-drift for CI integration

## Alert Types
- New cycles detected (critical)
- Significant PageRank changes (potential new bottleneck)
- Betweenness spike (new critical path node)
- Density increase (complexity growing)

## Success Criteria
- CI can run --check-drift and fail on regressions
- Clear exit codes: 0=OK, 1=critical, 2=warning
- Human-readable and JSON output available

title: Epic Emoji Inconsistent Across Codebase (VS-16 Issues)
description:
## Problem Statement

The epic issue type uses inconsistent emoji across the codebase. Some files use the mountain emoji with VS-16 variation selector (causes terminal width issues), while others were updated to use the rocket emoji. This inconsistency causes column misalignment in some terminal emulators.

## User Impact

**Severity: Medium (P2)**
- Visual glitch causes column misalignment
- Affects WezTerm, Alacritty, and other terminals with limited VS-16 support
- Reported by @ghillb in GitHub Issue #6 with excellent technical analysis
- Also affects keyboard emoji in help overlay per @rbergman

## Root Cause Analysis

### The VS-16 Problem

Unicode Variation Selector-16 (U+FE0F) requests emoji presentation. The mountain emoji:
- With VS-16: U+1F3D4 U+FE0F renders as 3 cells in many terminals
- Without VS-16: U+1F3D4 renders as 2 cells consistently

WezTerm has documented 0% VS-16 support, causing the emoji to occupy incorrect width.

### Current Inconsistency

**Already fixed (uses rocket):**
- `pkg/ui/theme.go:108-110`: Returns "rocket" with comment explaining VS-16 issue

**Still broken (uses mountain with VS-16):**
- `pkg/ui/model.go:2596`: GetTypeIconMD() returns "mountain"
- `pkg/export/markdown.go:323`: getTypeEmoji() returns "mountain"
- Various tests reference the old emoji

```
  ğŸ“‹ P1 OPEN proj-abc Task item...
  ğŸ“‹ P1 OPEN proj-def Another task...
  ğŸ”ï¸  P1 OPEN proj-ghi Epic item...  â† misaligned (3 cells)
  âœ¨ P2 OPEN proj-jkl Feature...
```

## Proposed Solution

### 1. Audit all emoji usage

Search for problematic emojis across codebase:
- Mountain: U+1F3D4 (ğŸ”ï¸ with or without VS-16)
- Keyboard: U+2328 U+FE0F (âŒ¨ï¸ in help overlay)
- Any other emojis with VS-16

### 2. Standardize to VS-16-free versions

```go
// theme.go already does this:
case "epic":
    return "rocket", t.Epic  // No VS-16

// Update model.go GetTypeIconMD():
func GetTypeIconMD(typ string) string {
    switch typ {
    case "epic":
        return "rocket"  // Changed from mountain
    // ...
    }
}

// Update export/markdown.go getTypeEmoji():
func getTypeEmoji(typ string) string {
    switch typ {
    case "epic":
        return "rocket"  // Changed from mountain
    // ...
    }
}
```

### 3. Update tests

Ensure all test expectations use the new emoji.

### 4. Document emoji choices

Add comment in theme.go explaining why certain emojis are chosen and what to avoid.

## Design Considerations

1. **Which emoji for epic?**
   - Current fix uses rocket (no VS-16 issues)
   - Could use books (ğŸ“š) as suggested in issue
   - Rocket makes sense: launch, major milestone
   - **Decision**: Stick with rocket for consistency with theme.go fix

2. **Should we strip VS-16 programmatically?**
   - Could filter emojis at render time
   - Adds complexity for edge case
   - **Decision**: Use VS-16-free emojis directly (simpler)

## Test Plan

1. Verify all emoji definitions use VS-16-free versions
2. Run grep/search for U+FE0F patterns
3. Manual test in WezTerm (0% VS-16 support)
4. Verify column alignment with mixed issue types

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All epic emojis use rocket (or chosen alternative)
- [ ] No VS-16 (U+FE0F) in any emoji definitions
- [ ] Columns align correctly in WezTerm
- [ ] Tests updated to expect new emojis
- [ ] Documentation added explaining emoji guidelines

## References

- GitHub Issue #6: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/6
- WezTerm VS-16 issue: https://github.com/wezterm/wezterm/issues/3923
- Unicode VS-16 terminal support: https://www.jeffquast.com/post/ucs-detect-test-results/
- WezTerm UCS detection results (0% VS-16): https://ucs-detect.readthedocs.io/sw_results/wezterm.html

title: Rust WASM Graph Engine for Static Viewer
description:
# Rust WASM Graph Engine for Static Viewer

## Overview
Add a Rust-compiled WASM module to the static viewer that enables **live graph calculations** on filtered data. Since we're already shipping sql.js WASM for database queries, adding a graph WASM module is a natural extension that unlocks powerful interactive features impossible with pre-computed data.

## Motivation: Why WASM for Graph Calculations?

### The Limitation of Pre-Computed Metrics
The current static export computes all graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, etc.) at export time and stores them in SQLite. This works well for full-dataset views, but falls short when users:

1. **Filter to a subset**: PageRank of issues in the "auth" label â‰  pre-computed PageRank
2. **Ask "what-if" questions**: "If I close bv-123, what unblocks?"
3. **Explore dependencies**: "Show me the critical path for just P1 issues"
4. **Analyze subgraphs**: "Are there cycles within just the API work?"

### What Rust WASM Enables
With client-side graph computation, the static viewer can:

- **Live PageRank**: Recompute centrality on any filtered subset
- **What-If Simulation**: Preview cascade effects before closing issues
- **Subgraph Analysis**: Detect cycles, critical paths within filtered views
- **Impact Preview**: Hover to see downstream effects
- **Dynamic Exploration**: "What gets unblocked if I close these 3 issues?"

### Performance Comparison (estimated on 1000-node graph)
| Algorithm | JavaScript | Rust WASM | Speedup |
|-----------|-----------|-----------|---------|
| PageRank | ~200ms | ~5ms | 40x |
| Betweenness | ~2000ms | ~50ms | 40x |
| Cycle Detection | ~500ms | ~10ms | 50x |
| Critical Path | ~100ms | ~3ms | 33x |
| Topological Sort | ~50ms | ~2ms | 25x |

### Bundle Size Impact
- **bv_graph_bg.wasm**: ~80-120KB (wasm-opt optimized)
- **bv_graph.js**: ~15KB (wasm-bindgen glue)
- **Total**: ~100-135KB (acceptable; sql-wasm.wasm is ~1MB)

## Technical Architecture

### Rust Crate Structure
```
bv-graph-wasm/
  Cargo.toml
  src/
    lib.rs              # WASM bindings via wasm-bindgen
    graph.rs            # Core DiGraph structure with adjacency lists
    algorithms/
      mod.rs
      pagerank.rs       # PageRank with damping factor
      betweenness.rs    # Exact + approximate (Brandes sampling)
      eigenvector.rs    # Power iteration
      hits.rs           # Hub/Authority scores
      topo.rs           # Topological sort, Kahn's algorithm
      cycles.rs         # Tarjan SCC + cycle enumeration
      critical_path.rs  # Heights/depths in DAG
      kcore.rs          # K-core decomposition
      articulation.rs   # Tarjan's cut vertices
      slack.rs          # Critical path slack
    whatif.rs           # What-if simulation API
    subgraph.rs         # Subgraph extraction, reachability
  tests/
    integration_test.rs # Cross-algorithm tests
```

### WASM Interface Design
```rust
#[wasm_bindgen]
pub struct DiGraph {
    nodes: Vec<String>,           // Node ID strings
    node_index: HashMap<String, usize>,
    adj: Vec<Vec<usize>>,         // Forward adjacency
    rev_adj: Vec<Vec<usize>>,     // Reverse adjacency
}

#[wasm_bindgen]
impl DiGraph {
    #[wasm_bindgen(constructor)]
    pub fn new() -> DiGraph;
    
    // Graph construction
    pub fn add_node(&mut self, id: &str) -> usize;
    pub fn add_edge(&mut self, from: usize, to: usize);
    pub fn node_count(&self) -> usize;
    pub fn edge_count(&self) -> usize;
    
    // Algorithms (return JSON for complex types)
    pub fn pagerank(&self, damping: f64, iterations: u32) -> Vec<f64>;
    pub fn betweenness(&self) -> Vec<f64>;
    pub fn betweenness_approx(&self, sample_size: usize) -> Vec<f64>;
    pub fn eigenvector(&self, iterations: u32) -> Vec<f64>;
    pub fn hits(&self, iterations: u32) -> JsValue; // {hubs: [], authorities: []}
    pub fn topological_sort(&self) -> Vec<usize>;
    pub fn detect_cycles(&self) -> JsValue; // [[cycle1], [cycle2], ...]
    pub fn critical_path_heights(&self) -> Vec<f64>;
    pub fn kcore(&self) -> Vec<u32>;
    pub fn articulation_points(&self) -> Vec<usize>;
    pub fn slack(&self) -> Vec<f64>;
    
    // Subgraph operations
    pub fn subgraph(&self, node_indices: &[usize]) -> DiGraph;
    pub fn reachable_from(&self, node: usize) -> Vec<usize>;
    pub fn reachable_to(&self, node: usize) -> Vec<usize>;
    
    // What-if simulation
    pub fn what_if_close(&self, node: usize) -> JsValue; // {direct, transitive, ids}
}
```

### JavaScript Integration
```javascript
import init, { DiGraph } from './vendor/bv_graph.js';

let GRAPH_ENGINE = null;

async function initGraphEngine() {
    await init();
    GRAPH_ENGINE = new DiGraph();
    
    // Load edges from SQLite
    const deps = db.exec('SELECT issue_id, depends_on_id FROM dependencies');
    const nodeMap = new Map();
    
    for (const [from, to] of deps[0].values) {
        if (!nodeMap.has(from)) nodeMap.set(from, GRAPH_ENGINE.add_node(from));
        if (!nodeMap.has(to)) nodeMap.set(to, GRAPH_ENGINE.add_node(to));
        GRAPH_ENGINE.add_edge(nodeMap.get(from), nodeMap.get(to));
    }
    
    return nodeMap;
}

// Live recalculation example
function recalculateForFilter(filteredIds) {
    const indices = filteredIds.map(id => NODE_MAP.get(id)).filter(Boolean);
    const subgraph = GRAPH_ENGINE.subgraph(indices);
    
    return {
        pagerank: subgraph.pagerank(0.85, 100),
        cycles: JSON.parse(subgraph.detect_cycles()),
        criticalPath: subgraph.critical_path_heights(),
    };
}
```

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Core Infrastructure
- Set up Rust workspace with wasm-bindgen
- Implement DiGraph structure with adjacency lists
- Add wasm-pack build pipeline
- Integrate into bv build system

### Phase 2: Algorithm Porting (from pkg/analysis/graph.go)
- Port PageRank (power iteration)
- Port Betweenness (exact + approximate)
- Port Eigenvector centrality
- Port HITS algorithm
- Port Topological sort
- Port Cycle detection (Tarjan SCC + enumeration)
- Port Critical path heights
- Port K-core decomposition
- Port Articulation points
- Port Slack computation

### Phase 3: Advanced Operations
- Subgraph extraction
- Reachability queries (from/to)
- What-if simulation API

### Phase 4: JavaScript Integration
- Initialize from SQLite data
- Live recalculation hooks
- Fallback for WASM failures
- Performance monitoring

### Phase 5: UI Features
- "Recalculate" button for filtered views
- "What-If" panel for impact analysis
- Live metrics updates on filter change
- Subgraph highlighting

### Phase 6: Testing & Optimization
- Port Go tests to Rust
- Cross-validate with Go implementation
- JavaScript integration tests
- wasm-opt size optimization
- Benchmarks

## Fallback Strategy
If WASM fails to load (old browser, security policy, etc.):
1. Use pre-computed values from SQLite
2. Disable live recalculation features
3. Show "Limited Mode" indicator
4. Graceful degradation - everything still works, just no live updates

## Success Criteria
1. WASM module loads reliably across browsers
2. PageRank on 1000 nodes completes in <50ms
3. All algorithms match Go implementation results
4. Bundle size increase <150KB
5. Fallback works when WASM unavailable
6. Live recalculation enabled in filtered views

## References
- bv pkg/analysis/graph.go: Go implementations to port
- bv pkg/analysis/betweenness_approx.go: Approximate betweenness
- bv pkg/analysis/whatif.go: What-if simulation patterns
- wasm-bindgen: https://rustwasm.github.io/wasm-bindgen/
- wasm-pack: https://rustwasm.github.io/wasm-pack/

title: Bead History & Code Correlation System
description:
# Bead History & Code Correlation System

## Overview
Implement a system to track the full lifecycle of beads (creation, claim, modification, closure) and correlate them with the git commits that implemented the work. This enables traceability from issue to code without requiring LLM inference.

## User Stories
- As a project lead, I want to see what code changes were made for each bead
- As a developer, I want to know which bead drove a particular commit
- As an AI agent, I want structured JSON data about bead-to-commit relationships
- As a code reviewer, I want to understand the context behind changes

## The Core Insight
The git history of beads.jsonl IS the source of truth:
1. **Exact timestamps** - when each bead was created, modified, closed
2. **Git author** - the agent/person who made each change  
3. **Commit SHA** - links to all other files changed in that commit

This creates a direct, mechanical correlation chain with no LLM needed.

## Correlation Methods (by confidence)
| Method | Confidence | Description |
|--------|------------|-------------|
| co_committed | 95-99% | Code changed in same commit as bead status change |
| explicit_id | 90-95% | Commit message contains bead ID |
| temporal_author | 40-70% | Same author, within bead's active window |

## Success Criteria
- [ ] \`bv --robot-history\` outputs structured JSON of all correlations
- [ ] \`bv --bead-history <id>\` shows history for a specific bead
- [ ] TUI shows history in detail pane and dedicated view
- [ ] Co-committed correlations have >95% accuracy
- [ ] Performance: <2s for repos with 1000 commits

## Non-Goals (for initial release)
- Real-time commit watching (future enhancement)
- GitHub/GitLab PR integration (future enhancement)
- Automatic bead creation from commits (different feature)

## Implementation Phases
1. **Phase 1 (MVP)**: Core extraction + robot-history flag
2. **Phase 2**: Additional correlation methods + confidence scoring
3. **Phase 3**: TUI integration
4. **Phase 4**: Performance optimization
5. **Phase 5**: Testing and documentation

See docs/bead-history-feature-plan.md for complete specification.

description:
# Data Types for Bead History Correlation

## Context
This is the foundational task - all other history features depend on these types being well-designed. Getting this right is critical.

## Types to Define

### BeadEvent
Represents a single lifecycle event for a bead, extracted from git history.

\`\`\`go
type BeadEvent struct {
    BeadID      string    \`json:"bead_id"\`
    EventType   EventType \`json:"event_type"\`
    Timestamp   time.Time \`json:"timestamp"\`
    CommitSHA   string    \`json:"commit_sha"\`
    CommitMsg   string    \`json:"commit_message"\`
    Author      string    \`json:"author"\`       // Git author name
    AuthorEmail string    \`json:"author_email"\` // Git author email
}

type EventType string
const (
    EventCreated  EventType = "created"      // Bead first appears in file
    EventClaimed  EventType = "claimed"      // Status changed to in_progress
    EventClosed   EventType = "closed"       // Status changed to closed
    EventReopened EventType = "reopened"     // Status changed FROM closed
    EventModified EventType = "modified"     // Other significant changes
)
\`\`\`

### CorrelatedCommit
A code commit linked to a bead with confidence metadata.

\`\`\`go
type CorrelatedCommit struct {
    SHA           string            \`json:"sha"\`
    ShortSHA      string            \`json:"short_sha"\`
    Message       string            \`json:"message"\`
    Author        string            \`json:"author"\`
    AuthorEmail   string            \`json:"author_email"\`
    Timestamp     time.Time         \`json:"timestamp"\`
    Files         []FileChange      \`json:"files"\`
    Method        CorrelationMethod \`json:"method"\`
    Confidence    float64           \`json:"confidence"\`
    Reason        string            \`json:"reason"\`
}

type FileChange struct {
    Path       string \`json:"path"\`
    Action     string \`json:"action"\`     // A=added, M=modified, D=deleted
    Insertions int    \`json:"insertions"\`
    Deletions  int    \`json:"deletions"\`
}

type CorrelationMethod string
const (
    MethodCoCommitted    CorrelationMethod = "co_committed"
    MethodExplicitID     CorrelationMethod = "explicit_id"
    MethodTemporalAuthor CorrelationMethod = "temporal_author"
)
\`\`\`

### BeadHistory
The complete correlation record for a single bead.

### HistoryReport
The top-level output structure for --robot-history.

## Design Decisions
- Separate Events from milestones (Created/Claimed/Closed) for quick access
- Include CommitIndex in HistoryReport for O(1) reverse lookup
- CycleTime as pointer since not all beads have been closed

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/types.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. All types compile without errors
2. JSON tags are consistent and documented
3. String methods implemented for enum types
4. Unit tests for serialization roundtrips
5. Go doc comments on all exported types

# Git History Parser for beads.jsonl

## Context
This is the core extraction logic. We parse \`git log -p -- .beads/beads.jsonl\` to extract bead lifecycle events.

## Git Command
\`\`\`bash
git log -p --follow --format="%H|%aI|%an|%ae|%s" -- .beads/beads.jsonl
\`\`\`

## Parsing Algorithm
1. Run git log command
2. Parse output commit by commit
3. For each commit:
   a. Parse commit metadata (SHA, timestamp, author, message)
   b. Parse the diff section
   c. For each changed line in diff:
      - Parse old JSON (lines starting with -)
      - Parse new JSON (lines starting with +)
      - Detect what changed (new bead, status change, other)
      - Create BeadEvent records
4. Return chronologically sorted events

## Diff Parsing Details

### Detecting Bead Creation
\`\`\`diff
+{"id":"AUTH-123","title":"Fix login","status":"open",...}
\`\`\`
A line starting with \`+\` containing valid JSON = EventCreated

### Detecting Status Changes
\`\`\`diff
-{"id":"AUTH-123",...,"status":"open",...}
+{"id":"AUTH-123",...,"status":"in_progress",...}
\`\`\`
Same bead ID, different status = appropriate event type

## Edge Cases to Handle
1. Malformed JSON lines: Skip with warning
2. Multiple beads changed in one commit: Generate event for each
3. Empty commits: No events generated
4. Merge commits: Parse like regular commits

## Options Structure
\`\`\`go
type ExtractOptions struct {
    Since     time.Time  // Only commits after this time
    Until     time.Time  // Only commits before this time
    Limit     int        // Max commits to process
    BeadID    string     // Filter to single bead ID
}
\`\`\`

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/extractor.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Correctly parses sample git log output
2. Handles all edge cases without panic
3. Returns chronologically sorted events
4. Supports filtering options
5. Unit tests with mock git output

title: Implement co-committed file extraction
description:
# Co-Committed File Extraction

## Context
This is the highest-confidence correlation method (95-99%). When a bead status changes and code files change in THE SAME COMMIT, that's a direct causal link.

## Why This Works
Developer workflow:
1. Write code to implement feature
2. Mark bead as closed
3. Commit both changes together

The code files in that commit ARE the implementation of the bead.

## Git Command
\`\`\`bash
git show --name-status --format="" <sha>
\`\`\`

Output:
\`\`\`
M       pkg/auth/login.go
M       pkg/auth/session.go
M       .beads/beads.jsonl
\`\`\`

## Algorithm
1. For each BeadEvent with status change (claimed/closed)
2. Run \`git show --name-status\` for that commit
3. Filter OUT bead files (.beads/*)
4. Return code files only as CorrelatedCommit records

## What Counts as "Code Files"?
Include: .go, .py, .js, .ts, .rs, .java, .yaml, .json, .md
Exclude: .beads/*, .bv/*, .git/*, node_modules/, vendor/

## Getting Line Stats
\`\`\`bash
git show --numstat --format="" <sha>
\`\`\`

## Confidence Scoring
Base: 0.95

Adjustments:
- Commit message mentions bead ID: +0.04 â†’ 0.99
- >20 files changed (shotgun commit): -0.10 â†’ 0.85
- Only test files changed: -0.05 â†’ 0.90

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/cocommit.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Correctly extracts co-committed files for any commit
2. Filters out bead files and non-code files
3. Includes insertion/deletion stats
4. Applies confidence adjustments correctly
5. Handles commits with no code files gracefully

title: Implement explicit bead ID matching in commit messages
description:
# Explicit Bead ID Matching

## Context
Many developers include bead/issue IDs in commit messages:
- "fix(auth): resolve login bug [AUTH-123]"
- "Closes AUTH-123"
- "Refs: beads-456, beads-789"

This is high-confidence (90-95%) because the developer explicitly linked them.

## Pattern Matching
\`\`\`go
var beadIDPatterns = []*regexp.Regexp{
    // [ID] format
    regexp.MustCompile(\`\\[([A-Z]+-\\d+)\\]\`),
    
    // Closes/Fixes/Refs keywords
    regexp.MustCompile(\`(?i)closes?\\s+#?([A-Z]+-\\d+)\`),
    regexp.MustCompile(\`(?i)fix(?:es|ed)?\\s+#?([A-Z]+-\\d+)\`),
    regexp.MustCompile(\`(?i)refs?\\s+#?([A-Z]+-\\d+)\`),
    
    // beads-123 format
    regexp.MustCompile(\`(?i)beads?[-_](\\d+)\`),
    
    // Generic ID at word boundary
    regexp.MustCompile(\`\\b([A-Z]{2,10}-\\d+)\\b\`),
}
\`\`\`

## Finding Commits with Explicit References
\`\`\`bash
git log --grep="AUTH-123" --format="%H|%aI|%an|%ae|%s" --all
\`\`\`

## Confidence Scoring
Base: 0.90

Adjustments:
- "Closes" or "Fixes" keyword: +0.05 â†’ 0.95
- Multiple IDs in message: -0.02 per extra ID
- ID in brackets [AUTH-123]: +0.02

## Avoiding Duplicates
If already correlated via co-committed, don't add explicit-id duplicate.
If both methods apply, keep co-committed (higher confidence).

## Configurable Patterns
Allow users to add custom patterns in .bv/config.yaml:
\`\`\`yaml
history:
  id_patterns:
    - '\\bJIRA-\\d+\\b'
    - '\\bGH-\\d+\\b'
\`\`\`

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/explicit.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Extracts bead IDs from various message formats
2. Uses git --grep for efficient searching
3. Avoids duplicate correlations
4. Supports custom patterns from config
5. Unit tests for pattern matching
close_reason: Implemented ExplicitMatcher with pattern matching for commit messages. Supports bracket format, action keywords (closes/fixes/refs/resolves), beads/bv format, and generic PROJECT-ID format. Confidence scoring based on match type. All tests passing.

title: Implement confidence scoring model
description:
# Confidence Scoring Model

## Context
Different correlation methods have different reliability. We need a consistent model for expressing and combining confidence scores.

## Confidence Ranges by Method
| Method | Range | Description |
|--------|-------|-------------|
| co_committed | 0.90-0.99 | Direct causation |
| explicit_id | 0.85-0.95 | Developer intent |
| temporal_author | 0.40-0.75 | Same person, right time |

## Combining Multiple Signals
If a commit matches multiple methods:
\`\`\`go
func CombineConfidence(scores []float64) float64 {
    // Use highest as base
    sort.Float64s(scores)
    base := scores[len(scores)-1]
    
    // Boost slightly for each additional signal
    for i := 0; i < len(scores)-1; i++ {
        boost := (1.0 - base) * 0.1 * scores[i]
        base += boost
    }
    
    return min(base, 0.99)
}
\`\`\`

## Filtering by Confidence
Support \`--min-confidence\` flag:
\`\`\`bash
bv --robot-history --min-confidence 0.7
\`\`\`

## Confidence Explanation
Generate human-readable explanations:
- "Changed in same commit as bead update"
- "Commit message mentions AUTH-123"
- "By bob@dev during active window"

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/scorer.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Each method has defined confidence range
2. Multiple signals combine correctly
3. \`--min-confidence\` filter works
4. Explanations are human-readable
5. Scores are deterministic (same input = same output)
close_reason: Confidence scoring model complete: CombineConfidence function, MethodRanges definitions, FilterByConfidence, --min-confidence CLI flag added and documented. All acceptance criteria met.

title: Define static export data structures and JSON schema
description:
# Define SQLite Export Schema and Materialized Views

## Context
Following mcp_agent_mail's proven architecture, we'll export to SQLite and query it client-side using sql.js WASM. This is more sophisticated than JSON but provides:
- Real full-text search via FTS5
- Complex queries (dependencies, blocked chains)
- Materialized views for fast common operations
- Chunked loading for large datasets
- OPFS caching for offline support

## Database Schema

### Core Tables (exported from beads)
```sql
CREATE TABLE issues (
    id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    title TEXT NOT NULL,
    description TEXT,
    status TEXT NOT NULL,
    priority INTEGER NOT NULL,
    issue_type TEXT NOT NULL,
    assignee TEXT,
    labels TEXT, -- JSON array, indexed via FTS
    created_at TEXT NOT NULL,
    updated_at TEXT NOT NULL,
    closed_at TEXT
);

CREATE TABLE dependencies (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    issue_id TEXT NOT NULL,
    depends_on_id TEXT NOT NULL,
    type TEXT NOT NULL, -- 'blocks', 'related', 'parent-child'
    FOREIGN KEY (issue_id) REFERENCES issues(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (depends_on_id) REFERENCES issues(id)
);

-- Graph metrics (computed by bv analysis)
CREATE TABLE issue_metrics (
    issue_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    pagerank REAL,
    betweenness REAL,
    critical_path_depth INTEGER,
    triage_score REAL,
    blocks_count INTEGER,
    blocked_by_count INTEGER,
    FOREIGN KEY (issue_id) REFERENCES issues(id)
);
```

### FTS5 Full-Text Search
```sql
CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE issues_fts USING fts5(
    id,
    title,
    description,
    labels,
    assignee,
    content='issues',
    content_rowid='rowid'
);

-- Triggers to keep FTS in sync (export-time only)
```

### Materialized Views
```sql
-- Denormalized issue overview (like mcp_agent_mail's message_overview_mv)
CREATE TABLE issue_overview_mv AS
SELECT 
    i.id,
    i.title,
    i.description,
    i.status,
    i.priority,
    i.issue_type,
    i.assignee,
    i.labels,
    i.created_at,
    i.updated_at,
    i.closed_at,
    m.pagerank,
    m.betweenness,
    m.critical_path_depth,
    m.triage_score,
    m.blocks_count,
    m.blocked_by_count,
    (SELECT GROUP_CONCAT(depends_on_id) FROM dependencies WHERE issue_id = i.id AND type = 'blocks') as blocks_ids,
    (SELECT GROUP_CONCAT(issue_id) FROM dependencies WHERE depends_on_id = i.id AND type = 'blocks') as blocked_by_ids
FROM issues i
LEFT JOIN issue_metrics m ON i.id = m.issue_id;

-- Pre-computed triage recommendations
CREATE TABLE triage_recommendations_mv AS
SELECT 
    id,
    title,
    issue_type,
    status,
    priority,
    triage_score,
    blocks_count,
    -- reasoning computed from analysis
    json_group_array(reason) as reasons
FROM (
    SELECT ... -- populated from --robot-triage output
);
```

### Performance Indexes
```sql
-- Covering indexes for common queries
CREATE INDEX idx_issues_status ON issues(status);
CREATE INDEX idx_issues_priority ON issues(priority, status);
CREATE INDEX idx_issues_updated ON issues(updated_at DESC);
CREATE INDEX idx_issues_type_status ON issues(issue_type, status);
CREATE INDEX idx_deps_issue ON dependencies(issue_id);
CREATE INDEX idx_deps_depends ON dependencies(depends_on_id);
CREATE INDEX idx_metrics_score ON issue_metrics(triage_score DESC);
```

### Export Metadata Table
```sql
CREATE TABLE export_meta (
    key TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    value TEXT
);
-- Contains: version, generated_at, git_commit, issue_count, etc.
```

## Export Optimization (from mcp_agent_mail)
```sql
-- Optimize for httpvfs streaming
PRAGMA journal_mode=DELETE;  -- Single file, no WAL
PRAGMA page_size=1024;       -- Optimal for range requests
INSERT INTO issues_fts(issues_fts) VALUES('optimize');
VACUUM;
ANALYZE;
PRAGMA optimize;
```

## File Output
```
outputDir/
  beads.sqlite3              # Main database
  beads.sqlite3.config.json  # Chunk config (if chunked)
  chunks/                    # Optional chunks for large DBs
  data/
    triage.json              # Full robot-triage output
    insights.json            # Full robot-insights output
    plan.json                # Full robot-plan output
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] SQLite schema defined with all tables
- [ ] FTS5 virtual table created and populated
- [ ] Materialized views pre-computed
- [ ] Performance indexes in place
- [ ] Export metadata table populated
- [ ] Database optimized for httpvfs (page_size, VACUUM)
- [ ] Unit tests verify schema and query patterns
- [ ] Integration test with real bv data

## Why SQLite over JSON
1. **Search**: FTS5 provides real full-text search with ranking
2. **Queries**: Can express complex dependency queries in SQL
3. **Scale**: Same approach works for 50 or 50,000 issues
4. **Performance**: Client queries only what it needs, not full load
5. **Caching**: OPFS support for offline use
6. **Proven**: mcp_agent_mail demonstrates this works well
notes:
REVISION (2025-12-16): Removed SearchText field from ExportIssue.

Rationale: Pre-computing search text wastes JSON bytes. The client can build search text on load by concatenating title + description + labels. This is a one-time O(n) operation that's fast enough for <1000 issues.

Updated ExportIssue struct:
```go
type ExportIssue struct {
    model.Issue
    PageRank        float64   `json:"pagerank"`
    Betweenness     float64   `json:"betweenness,omitempty"`
    CriticalPath    int       `json:"critical_path_depth"`
    BlocksCount     int       `json:"blocks_count"`
    BlockedByCount  int       `json:"blocked_by_count"`
    BlocksIDs       []string  `json:"blocks_ids,omitempty"`
    BlockedByIDs    []string  `json:"blocked_by_ids,omitempty"`
    // SearchText removed - client computes on load
}
```

Client-side search text generation:
```javascript
function buildSearchText(issue) {
  return [
    issue.id,
    issue.title,
    issue.description || '',
    (issue.labels || []).join(' '),
    issue.assignee || ''
  ].join(' ').toLowerCase();
}
```
close_reason:
Implemented SQLite export schema and Go data structures:
- Created sqlite_types.go with ExportIssue, ExportDependency, ExportMetrics, ExportMeta structs
- Created sqlite_schema.go with CreateSchema, CreateFTSIndex, CreateMaterializedViews, OptimizeDatabase
- Added comprehensive tests in sqlite_schema_test.go (all passing)
- Schema includes: issues, dependencies, issue_metrics, triage_recommendations, export_meta tables
- FTS5 full-text search support (works in sql.js browser environment)
- Materialized view issue_overview_mv for fast list queries
- Performance indexes for common query patterns
- Optimization functions for httpvfs streaming

title: Implement reverse lookup (commit â†’ bead)
description:
# Reverse Lookup: Commit â†’ Bead

## Context
Sometimes you're looking at a commit and want to know which bead it relates to.
"Why was this change made? What bead drove it?"

## Two Access Patterns
1. Via commit_index in HistoryReport (already built into structure)
2. Direct CLI query: \`bv --commit-bead <sha>\`

## New CLI Flag
\`\`\`bash
# Which bead(s) relate to this commit?
bv --commit-bead abc1234

# Output:
{
  "commit": "abc1234",
  "message": "fix(auth): resolve race condition",
  "related_beads": [
    {
      "bead_id": "AUTH-123",
      "bead_title": "Fix login race condition",
      "method": "co_committed",
      "confidence": 0.95
    }
  ]
}
\`\`\`

## Orphan Commit Detection
Commits that don't correlate to ANY bead:
\`\`\`go
func FindOrphanCommits(report *HistoryReport) []CommitInfo {
    correlated := make(map[string]bool)
    for sha := range report.CommitIndex {
        correlated[sha] = true
    }
    
    var orphans []CommitInfo
    for _, commit := range getAllCodeCommits() {
        if !correlated[commit.SHA] {
            orphans = append(orphans, commit)
        }
    }
    return orphans
}
\`\`\`

This is useful for code hygiene: "These commits have no associated bead!"

## Summary Stats Update
Add to HistorySummary:
- orphan_commits: Count of commits with no bead
- orphan_ratio: orphan_commits / total_commits

## File Location
- \`cmd/bv/main.go\` (new flag)
- \`pkg/correlation/reverse.go\` (lookup logic)

## Acceptance Criteria
1. \`--commit-bead <sha>\` outputs correct JSON
2. commit_index in report is accurate
3. Orphan detection works
4. Handles commits with multiple related beads
5. Handles commits with no related beads gracefully

title: Add --export-pages CLI flag and command handler
description:
# Add --export-pages CLI Flag and Command Handler

## Context
Add the core CLI interface for exporting static pages. This is the non-interactive version that can be used in CI/CD pipelines.

## Requirements

### New CLI Flags (cmd/bv/main.go)
```go
exportPages := flag.String("export-pages", "", "Export static site to directory (e.g., ./bv-pages)")
pagesTitle := flag.String("pages-title", "", "Custom title for static site")
pagesIncludeClosed := flag.Bool("pages-include-closed", false, "Include closed issues in export")
pagesMinify := flag.Bool("pages-minify", false, "Minify JSON output")
previewPages := flag.String("preview-pages", "", "Preview existing static site bundle")
```

### Command Flow
```go
if *exportPages != "" {
    config := export.ExportConfig{
        Title:         *pagesTitle,
        IncludeClosed: *pagesIncludeClosed,
        Minify:        *pagesMinify,
    }
    
    // Load issues (reuse existing loader)
    issues, err := loader.LoadFromPath(beadsPath)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    // Build graph (reuse existing analysis)
    graph := analysis.BuildGraph(issues)
    
    // Create exporter and run
    exporter := export.NewStaticExporter(issues, graph, config)
    if err := exporter.Export(*exportPages); err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    fmt.Printf("âœ“ Static site exported to: %s\n", *exportPages)
    fmt.Printf("  Open %s/index.html in a browser to view\n", *exportPages)
    os.Exit(0)
}
```

### Preview Mode
```go
if *previewPages != "" {
    // Start local HTTP server
    server := export.NewPreviewServer(*previewPages, 9000)
    fmt.Printf("Preview server running at http://localhost:%d\n", server.Port)
    fmt.Println("Press Ctrl+C to stop")
    
    // Open browser
    browser.Open(fmt.Sprintf("http://localhost:%d", server.Port))
    
    // Block until interrupted
    server.ListenAndServe()
    os.Exit(0)
}
```

### Output Messages
```
$ bv --export-pages ./bv-pages

Exporting static site...
  â†’ Loading issues from .beads/beads.jsonl

  bv --pages (interactive wizard)
```

### Error Handling

- No issues found: Warn but create empty site
- Graph analysis timeout: Use partial data with warning
- Write errors: Clean up partial output

title: Implement caching layer for history data
description:
# History Caching Layer

## Context
Parsing git history is expensive. We need to cache results to avoid re-parsing on every access.

## Cache Key
\`\`\`go
type CacheKey struct {
    HeadSHA       string  // Current git HEAD
    BeadsHash     string  // Hash of beads.jsonl content
    Options       string  // Serialized filter options
}
\`\`\`

## Cache Structure
\`\`\`go
type HistoryCache struct {
    mu      sync.RWMutex
    entries map[string]*CacheEntry
    maxAge  time.Duration
    maxSize int  // Max entries
}
\`\`\`

## Invalidation Strategy
Cache is invalid when:
- git HEAD changed (new commits)
- beads.jsonl content changed
- Cache entry older than maxAge (default: 5 minutes)

## Memory Management
- Default max entries: 10
- LRU eviction when full

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/cache.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Cache hit returns data without git calls
2. Cache invalidates on HEAD change
3. Cache invalidates on beads.jsonl change
4. LRU eviction works correctly
5. Thread-safe for concurrent access
6. Significant speedup on repeated access
close_reason: Implemented HistoryCache with LRU eviction, thread-safe access, auto-invalidation on HEAD/beads change, and CachedCorrelator wrapper with hit/miss stats

title: Support incremental history updates
description:
# Incremental History Updates

## Context
When only a few new commits exist since last cache, we shouldn't re-parse the entire history. Parse only new commits and merge.

## Algorithm
1. Find new commits since cached report (using LatestCommitSHA)
2. If few new commits (<100), parse only those
3. Merge new events with existing correlations
4. If too many new commits, full refresh is more efficient

## Track Latest Commit
Add to HistoryReport: LatestCommitSHA string

## Merge Logic
- New beads: Add to correlations
- Updated beads: Merge events, re-correlate if needed
- Existing correlations: Keep if still valid

## File Location
\`pkg/correlation/incremental.go\`

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Detects when incremental update is possible
2. Only parses new commits
3. Correctly merges with existing data
4. Falls back to full refresh when appropriate
5. Performance improvement measurable
close_reason: Implemented IncrementalCorrelator with LatestCommitSHA tracking, merge logic, and 100-commit threshold for fallback

title: Optimize for large repositories
description:
# Large Repository Optimization

## Context
For repos with 10,000+ commits, naive parsing is too slow. Need smarter strategies.

## Strategies

### 1. Default Commit Limit
\`\`\`go
const DefaultHistoryLimit = 500
\`\`\`

### 2. Streaming Parser
Don't load all git output into memory. Stream and parse line-by-line.

### 3. Parallel File Stats
Batch git show requests for multiple SHAs.

### 4. Skip Old Beads
\`--history-closed-since "90 days"\` - Only beads closed in last 90 days.

### 5. Progress Indicator
For TUI, show progress while loading:
\`\`\`
Loading history... 234/500 commits
\`\`\`

## Benchmarking Targets
- 100 commits: instant (<100ms)
- 1,000 commits: fast (<1s)
- 10,000 commits: acceptable (<5s)

## File Location
- \`pkg/correlation/stream.go\` (streaming parser)
- \`pkg/correlation/batch.go\` (batched git calls)

## Acceptance Criteria
1. 500 commit default limit
2. Streaming parser doesn't OOM
3. Batch file stats is faster than sequential
4. Progress indicator in TUI
5. Meets benchmark targets

title: Labels View & Dashboard System
description:
# Labels View & Dashboard System

## Overview
Implement a comprehensive Labels View that turns labels into a first-class organizational mechanism. This enables long-horizon task coordination by providing dashboards for feature areas (feat:auth), work types (fixes, ui), and epic progress tracking.

## Inspiration
Based on @kraitsura's Labels Viewer concept showing:
- Label selector with fuzzy search and progress bars
- Dashboard view grouping by EPICS and LABELS  
- Completion tracking (X/Y format with visual progress)
- Dependency depth toggle

## User Stories
- As a project lead, I want to see progress across feature areas at a glance
- As a developer, I want to quickly filter to issues with a specific label
- As a team, we want to track epic completion with roll-up statistics
- As anyone, I want fuzzy search to find labels quickly

## Key Features

### 1. Label Selector (Overlay)
- Fuzzy searchable picker accessible via \`l\` key from any view
- Shows all labels and epics with progress bars
- X/Y format showing completed vs total
- Checkmarks for 100% complete labels

### 2. Label Dashboard View  
- Dedicated view showing label statistics
- Two sections: EPICS (issues with type=epic) and LABELS
- Progress bars with completion percentages
- Expandable to drill into issues per label
- Section cycling: Ready/Blocked/InProgress/Closed

### 3. Dependency Depth Toggle
- \`d\` key cycles through 1/2/3/All depth levels
- Controls how deeply to show dependency chains
- Current depth shown in status bar

### 4. Visual Enhancements
- Distinction between labeled and unlabeled issues
- Epic progress roll-up from child issues
- Quick jump from dashboard to filtered list

## Keybindings
| Key | Action |
|-----|--------|
| l | Open label selector (global) |
| Enter | Select label / Confirm |
| Esc | Close selector / Back |
| j/k | Navigate |
| Tab | Cycle sections |
| d | Cycle dependency depth |

## Success Criteria
- [ ] \`l\` key opens label selector from any view
- [ ] Dashboard shows accurate progress for all labels
- [ ] Fuzzy search finds labels quickly
- [ ] Epic completion rolls up from children
- [ ] Dependency depth toggle works smoothly

## Implementation Phases
1. **Phase 1**: Label statistics extraction and data model
2. **Phase 2**: Label selector UI with fuzzy search
3. **Phase 3**: Label dashboard view
4. **Phase 4**: Integration, depth toggle, polish

Add natural language search via vector embeddings, enabling queries like 'memory leak issues' to find relevant results even without exact keyword matches.

- Embed title + description only
- Single embedding model

title: Interactive Graph Visualization with Force-Graph
description:
# Interactive Graph Visualization with Force-Graph

## Vision
Transform the static viewer from a simple table into an **immersive, interactive graph exploration experience**. Using [force-graph](https://github.com/vasturiano/force-graph) (WebGL-accelerated), users can explore their dependency graph visually, see patterns at a glance, and perform what-if analysis with beautiful animations.

## Why This Matters

### Current State: Tables Are Limiting
- Users scroll through lists, mentally reconstructing relationships
- Hard to see the "big picture" of work
- Bottlenecks and cycles are numbers, not visible patterns
- No way to explore "what if I close this?"

### Future State: Visual Graph Intelligence
- **See the shape** of your work at a glance
- **Spot bottlenecks** as large, central nodes
- **Find cycles** as visual loops
- **Explore what-if** by clicking nodes and watching cascades
- **Understand priority** through size, color, position

## Core Features

### 1. Force-Directed Dependency Graph
- Nodes = issues, sized by impact (PageRank/blocker count)
- Edges = dependencies with directional arrows
- Colors: green (closed), blue (open), orange (blocked), red (critical)
- Smooth WebGL rendering for 1000+ nodes at 60fps
- Click node to focus, hover for tooltip, drag to reorganize

### 2. Visual What-If Analysis
- Click any open issue to "simulate close"
- Watch downstream unblocks animate (ripple effect)
- See parallelization gain visually
- Color transitions: blockedâ†’unblocked nodes glow green
- Reset button to restore original state

### 3. Smart Clustering
- Automatic grouping by label using force clustering
- Label "galaxies" with distinct colors
- Cross-label edges show integration points
- Expand/collapse clusters
- Mini-map for navigation

### 4. Critical Path Highlighting
- Toggle to highlight longest dependency chain
- Animate path traversal
- Show "time to completion" along path
- Compare multiple paths

### 5. Time Travel Animation
- Scrubber to move through git history
- Watch graph grow/shrink over time
- See issues appear, get worked on, close
- Playback controls (play, pause, speed)

## Technical Architecture

### Library Choice: force-graph
- **Why**: WebGL-accelerated, handles 10k+ nodes, excellent API
- **CDN**: `https://unpkg.com/force-graph`
- **Alternative**: 3d-force-graph for even cooler 3D view
- **Fallback**: vis-network if WebGL unavailable

### Data Flow
```
SQLite â†’ JS â†’ WASM (metrics) â†’ force-graph (render)
                â†“
         User interaction
                â†“
         WASM (what-if) â†’ Animated update
```

### Performance Targets
- Initial render: <500ms for 500 nodes
- What-if calculation + animation: <100ms
- Smooth 60fps during interaction
- Memory: <100MB for 1000-node graph

## Visual Design Principles

1. **Clarity**: Important things are bigger, brighter
2. **Consistency**: Same colors mean same things everywhere
3. **Delight**: Smooth animations, satisfying interactions
4. **Accessibility**: Colorblind-safe palette, keyboard nav

## Success Metrics
- Users can identify top bottleneck in <5 seconds
- What-if takes <2 clicks to understand impact
- 90%+ of users prefer graph view over table for exploration
- Zero WebGL crashes/freezes

## Dependencies
- WASM Graph Engine (bv-5mgw) for metrics
- SQLite viewer infrastructure
- Static export with dependency data

## References
- force-graph: https://github.com/vasturiano/force-graph
- 3d-force-graph: https://github.com/vasturiano/3d-force-graph
- D3 force simulation: https://d3js.org/d3-force
- Graph viz inspiration: https://observablehq.com/@d3/force-directed-graph
