title: Set up Rust WASM crate with wasm-bindgen
description:
# Set up Rust WASM Crate with wasm-bindgen

## Context
This is the foundational task for the Rust WASM graph engine. We need a properly configured Rust workspace that compiles to WASM and integrates with the bv build system.

## Requirements

### Cargo.toml
```toml
[package]
name = "bv-graph-wasm"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"
authors = ["bv contributors"]
description = "High-performance graph algorithms for bv static viewer"
repository = "https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer"
license = "MIT"

[lib]
crate-type = ["cdylib", "rlib"]

[features]
default = ["console_error_panic_hook"]

[dependencies]
wasm-bindgen = "0.2"
js-sys = "0.3"
serde = { version = "1.0", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1.0"
console_error_panic_hook = { version = "0.1", optional = true }

[dev-dependencies]
wasm-bindgen-test = "0.3"

[profile.release]
# Optimize for size - critical for WASM bundles
opt-level = "s"
lto = true
codegen-units = 1
panic = "abort"
```

### Directory Structure
```
bv-graph-wasm/
  Cargo.toml
  Makefile                    # Build commands
  src/
    lib.rs                    # WASM entry point, panic hook
    graph.rs                  # DiGraph struct
    algorithms/
      mod.rs                  # Algorithm module exports
      pagerank.rs
      betweenness.rs
      eigenvector.rs
      hits.rs
      topo.rs
      cycles.rs
      critical_path.rs
      kcore.rs
      articulation.rs
      slack.rs
      density.rs
      degree.rs
    advanced/
      mod.rs
      topk_set.rs             # Greedy submodular selection
      coverage.rs             # Vertex cover
      k_paths.rs              # K-shortest paths
      parallel_cut.rs         # Parallelization analysis
      cycle_break.rs          # Cycle break suggestions
    whatif.rs                 # Impact simulation
    subgraph.rs               # Subgraph operations
    reachability.rs           # Reachability queries
  tests/
    web.rs                    # WASM integration tests
    algorithms/               # Algorithm unit tests
```

### lib.rs Skeleton
```rust
use wasm_bindgen::prelude::*;

mod graph;
mod algorithms;
mod advanced;
mod whatif;
mod subgraph;
mod reachability;

pub use graph::DiGraph;

// Initialize panic hook for better error messages in browser console
#[wasm_bindgen(start)]
pub fn init() {
    #[cfg(feature = "console_error_panic_hook")]
    console_error_panic_hook::set_once();
}

// Re-export main types for JavaScript
#[wasm_bindgen]
pub fn version() -> String {
    env!("CARGO_PKG_VERSION").to_string()
}
```

### Makefile
```makefile
.PHONY: build build-release test clean

# Development build (faster, larger)
build:
	wasm-pack build --target web --dev

# Release build (optimized)
build-release:
	wasm-pack build --target web --release
	wasm-opt -Os -o pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg_opt.wasm pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg.wasm
	mv pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg_opt.wasm pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg.wasm

# Run tests (in browser via wasm-pack)
test:
	wasm-pack test --headless --firefox

# Clean build artifacts
clean:
	cargo clean
	rm -rf pkg/

# Check size
size:
	@echo "WASM size:"
	@wc -c pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg.wasm
	@echo "Gzipped:"
	@gzip -c pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg.wasm | wc -c
```

### Integration with bv Build System
Add to main Makefile:
```makefile
wasm:
	cd bv-graph-wasm && make build-release
	cp bv-graph-wasm/pkg/bv_graph_wasm.js pkg/export/viewer_assets/vendor/bv_graph.js
	cp bv-graph-wasm/pkg/bv_graph_wasm_bg.wasm pkg/export/viewer_assets/vendor/bv_graph_bg.wasm
```

### Prerequisites Check
```bash
# Required tools
rustup --version          # Rust toolchain
cargo --version           # Rust package manager
wasm-pack --version       # WASM build tool
wasm-opt --version        # Binaryen optimizer (optional but recommended)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Cargo.toml configured with wasm-bindgen
- [ ] Directory structure created
- [ ] lib.rs compiles with `wasm-pack build`
- [ ] Output files generated in pkg/
- [ ] Makefile works for build/test/clean
- [ ] Release build produces <150KB WASM
- [ ] Integration with bv main Makefile
- [ ] README.md documents build process

## Why This Structure?
1. **Separate crate**: Clean boundary, independent testing
2. **wasm-pack**: Standard Rustâ†’WASM tooling
3. **wasm-opt**: Critical for size reduction (often 30-50% smaller)
4. **cdylib**: Required for WASM target
5. **console_error_panic_hook**: Better debugging in browser
6. **Module organization**: Matches Go pkg/analysis/ structure
notes: IMPORTANT: Use serde-wasm-bindgen instead of deprecated JsValue::from_serde. Add to Cargo.toml: serde-wasm-bindgen = "0.6". Use serde_wasm_bindgen::to_value() for JSON serialization to JS.

title: Optimize WASM bundle size with wasm-opt
description:
# Optimize WASM Bundle Size

## Context
WASM bundle size directly impacts load time. Target: <120KB gzipped.

## Optimization Steps

### 1. Cargo Profile
```toml
[profile.release]
opt-level = "s"     # Optimize for size
lto = true          # Link-time optimization
codegen-units = 1   # Better optimization
panic = "abort"     # Remove panic unwinding
```

### 2. wasm-opt (Binaryen)
```bash
wasm-opt -Os -o optimized.wasm unoptimized.wasm
```

### 3. Remove Unused Features
- Only include algorithms actually used
- Feature flags for optional algorithms
```toml
[features]
default = ["core"]
core = []  # PageRank, Betweenness, etc.
advanced = []  # TopK, Coverage, etc.
```

### 4. Measure and Report
```bash
# Before optimization
wc -c pkg/bv_graph_bg.wasm
gzip -c pkg/bv_graph_bg.wasm | wc -c

# After wasm-opt
wc -c pkg/bv_graph_bg_opt.wasm
gzip -c pkg/bv_graph_bg_opt.wasm | wc -c
```

### 5. Size Budget
| Component | Target | Max |
|-----------|--------|-----|
| Raw WASM | 100KB | 150KB |
| Gzipped | 50KB | 80KB |
| JS glue | 15KB | 25KB |

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Release build uses size optimizations
- [ ] wasm-opt applied in build pipeline
- [ ] Final size <120KB gzipped
- [ ] Size reported in CI output

title: Labels Missing from Detail View Panel
description:
## Problem Statement

Labels are NOT displayed in the detail view panel, even though they are a critical organizational feature. Users who rely on labels for categorization (e.g., `repo:web`, `area:backend`) cannot see this information when viewing issue details.

## User Impact

**Severity: High (P1)**
- Labels completely hidden in the most detailed view
- Users must use list view (width > 140px) to see labels at all
- Particularly problematic for multi-repo workflows using labels
- Reported by @neilpoulin in GitHub Issue #14 with screenshot

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `pkg/ui/model.go:2401-2498` (`updateViewportContent` function)

The detail view renders:
- Title with type icon âœ“
- Meta table (ID, Status, Priority, Assignee, Created) âœ“
- Graph Analysis metrics âœ“
- Description, Acceptance Criteria, Notes âœ“
- Dependency tree âœ“
- Comments âœ“
- History (if loaded) âœ“

**Missing:** Labels are never rendered\!

Labels ARE rendered in other contexts:
- List view delegate (`pkg/ui/delegate.go:97-99`) - but only when width > 140
- Copy to clipboard (`pkg/ui/model.go:2909-2910`)
- Kanban board (`pkg/ui/board.go:469-474`)

But `updateViewportContent()` simply doesn't include them.

## Proposed Solution

Add labels after the meta table, around line 2433:

```go
// After meta table, before Graph Analysis
if len(item.Labels) > 0 {
    sb.WriteString(fmt.Sprintf("**Labels:** %s\n\n", strings.Join(item.Labels, ", ")))
}
```

Or integrate into meta table as an additional row:

```go
// Extended meta table
sb.WriteString("| ID | Status | Priority | Assignee | Created | Labels |\n")
sb.WriteString("|---|---|---|---|---|---|\n")
labelsStr := strings.Join(item.Labels, ", ")
if labelsStr == "" { labelsStr = "-" }
sb.WriteString(fmt.Sprintf("| **%s** | **%s** | %s | @%s | %s | %s |\n\n",
    item.ID, strings.ToUpper(string(item.Status)), GetPriorityIcon(item.Priority),
    item.Assignee, item.CreatedAt.Format("2006-01-02"), labelsStr))
```

## Design Considerations

1. **Placement**: Should labels be in the meta table or as a separate section?
   - Meta table: Compact, consistent with other metadata
   - Separate section: More prominent, can be styled differently
   - **Recommendation**: Separate line after meta table for visibility

2. **Styling**: How should labels be formatted?
   - Simple comma-separated list (like clipboard function)
   - Styled tags with background colors
   - **Recommendation**: Start simple (comma-separated), enhance later if needed

3. **Empty state**: What if issue has no labels?
   - Don't render anything (current clipboard behavior)
   - Show "Labels: None" explicitly
   - **Recommendation**: Don't render if empty (cleaner)

## Test Plan

1. Test: Issue with multiple labels - all displayed
2. Test: Issue with no labels - section not rendered
3. Test: Issue with very long label list - wraps appropriately
4. Manual test: Labels visible in detail view for user's screenshot scenario

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Labels displayed in detail view panel
- [ ] No display when issue has no labels
- [ ] Markdown renders correctly (no escaping issues)
- [ ] Test coverage for with/without labels scenarios

## References

- GitHub Issue #14: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/14
- Screenshot in issue shows labels exist but don't display
- Related code: delegate.go:97-99, board.go:469-474 (where labels DO render)

title: Installer Script: TMP_DIRS Unbound Variable Error with set -u
description:
## Problem Statement

The install.sh script fails with an unbound variable error after successful installation when run with strict bash settings. The error occurs during cleanup when iterating over the TMP_DIRS array.

## User Impact

**Severity: Medium (P2)**
- Confusing error message after successful install
- Only affects new installations
- Reported by @tonywoode in GitHub Issue #7

## Error Message

```bash
$ curl -fsSL "...install.sh" | bash
==> Installing bv...
==> Detected platform: darwin_arm64
==> Checking for pre-built binary...
==> Latest release: v0.10.2
==> Selected asset: bv_0.10.2_darwin_arm64.tar.gz
==> Downloading...
==> Extracting...
==> Installed bv v0.10.2 to /opt/homebrew/bin/bv
==> Run 'bv' in any beads project to view issues.
bash: line 10: TMP_DIRS[@]: unbound variable    â† ERROR HERE
```

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `install.sh:2,8-14`

```bash
set -euo pipefail  # -u makes unbound variables an error

TMP_DIRS=()  # Empty array

cleanup_tmp_dirs() {
    local dir
    for dir in "${TMP_DIRS[@]}"; do  # FAILS when array is empty\!
        [ -n "$dir" ] && rm -rf "$dir"
    done
}

trap cleanup_tmp_dirs EXIT
```

With `set -u` (nounset), iterating over an empty array using `${TMP_DIRS[@]}` is an error in older bash versions. The array starts empty and if the binary install succeeds on the first try, no temp dirs are created.

## Why Installation Still Works

The error occurs in the EXIT trap AFTER the main script completes successfully. The binary is already installed when the cleanup function runs and fails.

## Proposed Solution

### Fix: Use array expansion that handles empty arrays

```bash
cleanup_tmp_dirs() {
    local dir
    # Use ${array[@]+"${array[@]}"} pattern for empty array safety
    for dir in "${TMP_DIRS[@]+"${TMP_DIRS[@]}"}"; do
        [ -n "$dir" ] && rm -rf "$dir"
    done
}
```

The `${var+value}` pattern returns nothing if var is unset/empty, avoiding the unbound error.

### Alternative: Check array length first

```bash
cleanup_tmp_dirs() {
    if [ ${#TMP_DIRS[@]} -gt 0 ]; then
        local dir
        for dir in "${TMP_DIRS[@]}"; do
            [ -n "$dir" ] && rm -rf "$dir"
        done
    fi
}
```

## Additional Bash Compatibility Considerations

While fixing this, audit for other bash compatibility issues:
- Array operations with set -u
- Local variable declarations
- Process substitution
- Bash version requirements

## Test Plan

1. Test: Fresh install on macOS (binary download path) - no error
2. Test: Install with fallback to source build - no error
3. Test: Install with no writable dirs (triggers temp dir creation) - no error
4. Test: Verify cleanup actually removes temp dirs when they exist
5. Test: Various bash versions (4.x, 5.x)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] No 'unbound variable' error after successful install
- [ ] Temp directories still cleaned up when created
- [ ] Works with bash 4.x and 5.x
- [ ] No regression in installation success rate
- [ ] Error handling for actual failures preserved

## Note on Issue #7

The original issue title mentions a 404 error, but that was a user typo in the URL (they had an extra 'github.com/Dicklesworthstone' in the path). Our README has the correct URL. The TMP_DIRS issue is the actual bug in our code.

## References

- GitHub Issue #7: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/7
- Bash empty array iteration: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7577052/
- set -u documentation: https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/The-Set-Builtin.html
close_reason: Fixed TMP_DIRS unbound variable by using bash array expansion pattern

title: Focus Isolation: List Selection Changes During Detail View Navigation
description:
## Problem Statement

When the detail view panel has focus (split view mode), pressing j/k or arrow keys to scroll the detail content ALSO changes the list selection in the left panel. The list visually updates to show a different selected item, even though the detail content being displayed doesn't change.

## User Impact

**Severity: Critical (P0)**
- Affects ALL users in split view mode
- Creates confusion about which issue is actually selected
- Breaks the mental model of focus isolation
- Reported by @ZainRizvi in GitHub Issue #12 with video evidence

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `pkg/ui/model.go:1116`

```go
// Update list for filtering input, but NOT for WindowSizeMsg
if _, isWindowSize := msg.(tea.WindowSizeMsg); !isWindowSize {
    m.list, cmd = m.list.Update(msg)  // â† PROBLEM: Called for ALL messages!
    cmds = append(cmds, cmd)
}
```

The bubbles `list.Model` component internally handles j/k keys for navigation. This code passes ALL keyboard messages to the list, regardless of current focus state. When in `focusDetail` mode:

1. `viewport.Update(msg)` is called (line 986) - correctly scrolls detail content
2. `list.Update(msg)` is ALSO called (line 1116) - incorrectly moves list selection

The second call happens because the guard only excludes WindowSizeMsg, not keyboard messages when focus is elsewhere.

## Why Detail Content Doesn't Change

The detail view shows the issue that was selected when `updateViewportContent()` was last called. Since this function is only triggered by explicit list selection changes (not by internal list.Update navigation), the displayed content stays the same even as the list cursor moves.

## Proposed Solution

Gate list updates by focus state. Only forward keyboard messages to the list when `m.focused == focusList` or when the message is a non-navigation type (like filtering input, WindowSizeMsg).

**Option A (Minimal change):**
```go
// Only update list selection when list has focus
if m.focused == focusList {
    if _, isWindowSize := msg.(tea.WindowSizeMsg); !isWindowSize {
        m.list, cmd = m.list.Update(msg)
        cmds = append(cmds, cmd)
    }
}
```

**Option B (More granular):**
Maintain list.Update for non-navigation messages (filtering, search) while blocking j/k/arrows when unfocused.

## Test Plan

1. Create test: Split view with focusDetail, send j/k keys, verify list index unchanged
2. Create test: Split view with focusList, send j/k keys, verify list index changes
3. Create test: Filtering input works regardless of focus
4. Manual test: Verify scroll in detail pane doesn't affect list selection
5. Manual test: Verify Tab switching focus works correctly

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] j/k in detail view scrolls content, doesn't change list selection
- [ ] j/k in list view still navigates as expected
- [ ] Tab correctly switches focus between panels
- [ ] Filter/search input still works from any focus state
- [ ] New tests pass with 100% coverage of focus scenarios

## References

- GitHub Issue #12: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/12
- Video demonstration in issue shows exact behavior
- Related code: handleListKeys(), focusDetail case at line 985-988
close_reason: Fixed focus isolation bug - gated list.Update on focusList state to prevent j/k keys from affecting list selection when detail view has focus

title: AI-Aware Kanban Autoprioritizer
description:
Use graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, freshness, blocker count) to suggest priority adjustments and surface high-impact items.

## Background & Motivation
The analysis package computes rich metrics but they're only visible in the insights panel. Users and agents want actionable recommendations: 'These 5 items should be prioritized because they unblock the most work.'

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: 'Smart suggestions' that explain why items should be reprioritized
- For AI Agents: --robot-priority provides a ranked work queue with reasoning

## Technical Approach
1. Create priority scoring function combining multiple metrics
2. Generate recommendations comparing current vs suggested priority
3. CLI: --robot-priority outputs priority-ranked JSON with explanations
4. TUI: 'Suggested' badge/indicator on items

## Scoring Function
impact_score = (
    0.3 * normalized_pagerank +
    0.3 * normalized_betweenness +
    0.2 * blocker_count / max_blocker_count +
    0.1 * freshness_penalty +
    0.1 * explicit_priority_boost
)

title: Implement priority scoring function
description:
Create composite scoring combining PageRank (30%), Betweenness (30%), Blocker count (20%), Staleness (10%), Explicit priority (10%).

## Algorithm
func (a *Analyzer) ComputeImpactScore(issue *model.Issue) ImpactScore:
  - Normalize all metrics to 0-1 range
  - Apply weights: 0.3*pagerank + 0.3*betweenness + 0.2*blockerRatio + 0.1*staleness + 0.1*priorityBoost
  - Return: IssueID, ImpactScore, ScoreBreakdown map

## Staleness Penalty
- Days since update, normalized: min(daysSinceUpdate / 30, 1.0)
- Older items get slight penalty to surface them

## Priority Boost
- P0=1.0, P1=0.75, P2=0.5, P3=0.25, P4=0.0 (higher priority = higher boost)

## File Changes
- pkg/analysis/priority.go: New scoring logic
- pkg/analysis/priority_test.go: Tests with known values

- 'Critical path bottleneck' (when Betweenness > 0.5)

## Confidence Calculation

title: Data Integrity: Merge Artifact Files Loaded Instead of Canonical Data
description:
## Problem Statement

bv can load stale/outdated issue data when merge artifact files (`beads.left.jsonl`, `beads.base.jsonl`) are present in the `.beads/` directory. Users see closed issues as open, wrong priorities, or missing issues entirely.

## User Impact

**Severity: Critical (P0)**
- Data integrity issue - users see WRONG information
- Particularly affects users after git merge conflicts
- Can lead to working on already-completed issues
- Reported by @bmjjr in GitHub Issue #5, confirmed by @masonjames

## Root Cause Analysis

**Location:** `pkg/loader/loader.go:36-56`

### Problem 1: Merge Artifacts Not Skipped

The `FindJSONLPath()` function skips files containing:
- `.backup`
- `.orig`  
- `.merge`
- `deletions.jsonl`

But it does NOT skip:
- `beads.left.jsonl` - Git merge artifact (OURS side)
- `beads.base.jsonl` - Git merge artifact (BASE side)

### Problem 2: Wrong Priority Order

```go
preferredNames := []string{"beads.jsonl", "beads.base.jsonl", "issues.jsonl"}
```

This prioritizes `beads.base.jsonl` (position #2) OVER `issues.jsonl` (position #3).

Per beads upstream (steveyegge/beads), `issues.jsonl` is the canonical file:
> Stage all tracked JSONL files (issues.jsonl is canonical, beads.jsonl for backward compat)

So the priority order is wrong AND merge artifacts aren't being filtered.

## Scenario That Triggers Bug

1. User has a beads project with `issues.jsonl` up to date
2. Git merge conflict occurs involving `.beads/` files
3. User resolves conflict but leaves `beads.left.jsonl` and `beads.base.jsonl` behind
4. bv loads `beads.base.jsonl` (old data) instead of `issues.jsonl` (current data)
5. User sees stale issue states

## Proposed Solution

### Fix 1: Skip merge artifact patterns

```go
// Skip backups, merge artifacts, and deletion manifests
if strings.Contains(name, ".backup") ||
    strings.Contains(name, ".orig") ||
    strings.Contains(name, ".merge") ||
    strings.HasPrefix(name, "beads.left") ||  // NEW
    strings.HasPrefix(name, "beads.base") ||  // NEW (when issues.jsonl exists)
    name == "deletions.jsonl" {
    continue
}
```

### Fix 2: Correct priority order

```go
// Priority order per beads upstream:
// 1. issues.jsonl (canonical)
// 2. beads.jsonl (backward compatibility)
// 3. beads.base.jsonl (only if nothing else exists)
preferredNames := []string{"issues.jsonl", "beads.jsonl", "beads.base.jsonl"}
```

### Fix 3: Add detection warning

When merge artifacts are detected, emit a warning to stderr:
```
Warning: Merge artifact files detected in .beads/. Run 'bd clean' to remove them.
Found: beads.left.jsonl, beads.base.jsonl
Loading from: issues.jsonl (canonical)
```

## Test Plan

1. Test: Directory with only issues.jsonl - loads correctly
2. Test: Directory with issues.jsonl AND beads.left.jsonl - skips artifact, loads issues.jsonl
3. Test: Directory with beads.jsonl AND issues.jsonl - loads issues.jsonl (new priority)
4. Test: Warning emitted when artifacts detected
5. Test: Fallback to beads.base.jsonl when NO other files exist

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] beads.left.jsonl always skipped
- [ ] beads.base.jsonl skipped when canonical file exists
- [ ] issues.jsonl prioritized over beads.jsonl
- [ ] Warning emitted for detected merge artifacts
- [ ] Existing tests updated, new tests added
- [ ] No regression for projects without merge artifacts

## Workaround (Current)

Users can run `bd clean` or manually delete merge artifact files.

## References

- GitHub Issue #5: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/issues/5
- beads pre-commit hook: https://github.com/steveyegge/beads/blob/main/.beads-hooks/pre-commit#L38
- Related: PR #18 (openInEditor hardcoded path) depends on this fix
close_reason: Fixed: 1) Skip beads.left/right merge artifacts, 2) Correct priority order (issues.jsonl canonical per beads upstream), 3) Add FindJSONLPathWithWarnings for merge artifact warnings. Tests added and passing.

title: Robot status output shows pending/empty states
description:
Problem:
- `bv --robot-plan` and `bv --robot-priority` emit `.status` with `state: pending` for all metrics and empty states for `KCore/Articulation/Slack`.
- This breaks the robot JSON contract and makes agents think metrics are still running even though bv exits immediately.

Repro:
- `bv --robot-plan | jq .status`
- `bv --robot-priority | jq .status`

Expected:
- Status should be deterministic and reflect what was actually computed for the command (`computed`/`approx`/`timeout`/`skipped`), with no `pending`/empty states.

Acceptance:
- `--robot-plan` and `--robot-priority` status fields never contain `pending`/empty states at process exit.
- If metrics are intentionally not computed for a fast path, they are marked `skipped` with a reason.
notes:
Implemented fix: `--robot-plan` and `--robot-priority` now wait for analysis completion before emitting `.status`, eliminating `pending`/empty states.

- `--robot-plan` skips expensive centrality metrics by default and marks them `skipped` with reason `not computed for --robot-plan`; still computes fast structural signals (k-core/articulation/slack) for a complete status contract.
- Tests updated to enforce no `pending`/empty states in robot outputs.

title: Topological Work-Plan Generator
description:
Leverage the existing DAG analysis to generate linearized, dependency-respecting work plans. This is the highest-value feature because it directly answers the question every developer and AI agent asks: 'What can I actually work on right now?'

## Background & Motivation
The analysis package already computes TopologicalOrder via topo.Sort(). However, this raw ordering isn't directly actionable because:
1. It includes closed issues
2. It doesn't filter to 'leaf nodes' (tasks with no open blockers)
3. It's not exposed via CLI for programmatic access

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: A 'Smart To-Do' view showing only actionable items eliminates cognitive overhead of scanning blocked tasks.
- For AI Agents: --robot-plan enables autonomous workflows where agents can request a strictly ordered task list, preventing work on blocked items.

## Technical Approach
1. Add GetActionableIssues() to analysis package - returns issues where all blocking dependencies are closed
2. Add GetExecutionPlan() - returns topologically sorted actionable items with parallel tracks identified
3. CLI flag --robot-plan outputs JSON with execution order
4. TUI view showing actionable items grouped by parallel tracks

## Success Criteria

- Plan respects all blocking dependencies
- Parallel tracks (independent work streams) are identified
- Zero actionable items shown when all open issues are blocked

func (a *Analyzer) GetActionableIssues() []model.Issue:

title: Add GetExecutionPlan() with parallel track detection
description:

type ExecutionPlan struct {

type ExecutionTrack struct {

}

type PlanItem struct {

## Overview

This epic tracks all bugs and feature requests identified from GitHub Issues (#5, #6, #7, #8, #12, #13, #14, #17) and PRs (#15, #16, #18) submitted by the community in late 2025. Each issue has been independently verified through code analysis.

## Background & Context

The bv (Beads Viewer) project received valuable community feedback identifying real bugs affecting user experience. While we don't accept outside code contributions, this feedback is essential for improving the tool.

### Why This Matters

bv is designed as an AI sidecar tool - a fast, reliable companion for issue triage. These bugs undermine that mission:

1. **Data Integrity Issues** - Showing stale/wrong data (#5) breaks user trust
2. **UX Friction** - Focus isolation bug (#12) affects every user session
3. **Feature Gaps** - Missing labels (#14) hides critical info
4. **Accessibility** - Light mode issues (#17) blocks users entirely
5. **Discoverability** - Help overlay limitations (#16) hurt onboarding

### Scope

**In Scope:** All verified bugs from community reports, related improvements, comprehensive test coverage.

**Out of Scope:** Major new features, architecture changes beyond fixes, performance optimizations.

### Success Criteria

1. All P0/P1 bugs resolved with tests
2. No regression in existing functionality
3. Community reporters can verify fixes

- pkg/ui/model.go - Focus handling, detail view, help overlay
- pkg/loader/loader.go - File selection, priority order

function dashboardView() {
  return {
    get stats() {
      const issues = Alpine.store('app').issues;
      return {
        open: issues.filter(i => i.status === 'open').length,
        actionable: Alpine.store('app').triage?.quick_ref?.actionable_count || 0,
        blocked: issues.filter(i => i.status === 'blocked').length,
        inProgress: issues.filter(i => i.status === 'in_progress').length
      };
    },
    
    get topPicks() {
      return Alpine.store('app').triage?.quick_ref?.top_picks || [];
    },
    
    get quickWins() {
      return Alpine.store('app').triage?.quick_wins?.slice(0, 5) || [];
    },
    
    get blockersToClose() {
      return Alpine.store('app').triage?.blockers_to_clear?.slice(0, 5) || [];
    },
    
    navigateToIssue(id) {
      window.location.hash = `/issue/${id}`;
    }
  };
}

title: Static Site Export & GitHub Pages Deployment
description:
# Static Site Export & GitHub Pages Deployment

## Overview
Add the ability to generate and deploy a slick static website that presents bv's issue tracker data to GitHub Pages (and optionally Cloudflare Pages). This feature mirrors the successful "shared mailbox" functionality in mcp_agent_mail, using the SAME proven SQLite + sql.js + FTS5 architecture.

## Motivation & Goals
1. **Shareability**: Allow teams to share project status without requiring bv installation
2. **Archival**: Create point-in-time snapshots of project health for stakeholders
3. **CI Integration**: Auto-publish project dashboards from CI pipelines
4. **Accessibility**: View rich analysis data in any browser

## Key Features
- **Dashboard View**: Quick stats (open/blocked/actionable), health indicators, top picks
- **Issues List**: Filterable/sortable by status, type, priority, labels, assignee
- **Issue Detail**: Full description, dependencies (blocks/blocked-by), graph position
- **Dependency Graph**: Interactive Mermaid.js visualization
- **Insights View**: PageRank leaders, bottlenecks, critical path, recommendations
- **Full-Text Search**: FTS5-powered search with ranking and snippets

## Technical Approach (Matching mcp_agent_mail)
| mcp_agent_mail Component | bv Equivalent |
|--------------------------|---------------|
| SQLite snapshot | SQLite export (beads.sqlite3) |
| sql.js WASM | sql.js WASM (client-side queries) |
| FTS5 full-text search | FTS5 full-text search |
| Materialized views | Materialized views (issue_overview_mv) |
| OPFS caching | OPFS caching (offline support) |
| Database chunking | Database chunking (>5MB) |
| Message list | Issues list with SQL filtering |
| Thread detail | Issue detail + dependency subgraph |
| Alpine.js + Tailwind | Same stack (proven, lightweight) |
| DOMPurify + Trusted Types | Same security approach |
| gh CLI deployment | Same approach |
| Cloudflare wrangler | Same approach |
| coi-serviceworker.js | Same (COOP/COEP for OPFS) |

## Bundle Structure
```
bv-pages/
  index.html              # SPA entry with CSP, COOP/COEP via service worker
  viewer.js               # Main app with sql.js integration
  styles.css              # Tailwind + custom styles
  beads.sqlite3           # Optimized SQLite database
  beads.sqlite3.config.json  # Chunk config (if chunked)
  chunks/                 # Database chunks (if >5MB)
  data/
    triage.json           # Full --robot-triage output
    insights.json         # Full --robot-insights output
    plan.json             # Full --robot-plan output
    meta.json             # Export metadata
  vendor/
    sql-wasm.js           # sql.js library
    sql-wasm.wasm         # SQLite WASM binary
    alpine.min.js         # Reactive UI framework
    marked.min.js         # Markdown rendering
    dompurify.min.js      # HTML sanitization
  coi-serviceworker.js    # COOP/COEP for GitHub Pages
  assets/
    favicon.svg
```

## Deployment Wizard Flow (Interactive)
1. Export options: select issues (all/filtered), include closed (yes/no)
2. Analysis: regenerate or use cached robot outputs
3. Target selection: GitHub Pages / Cloudflare Pages / Local only
4. Prerequisites check: gh/wrangler auth, git config, confirm identity
5. Preview: local server with hot reload
6. Deploy: create/update repo (with safety checks), push, enable Pages

## CLI Commands
```bash
# Full wizard (interactive)
bv --pages

# Quick export to directory
bv --export-pages ./bv-pages

# Export with options
bv --export-pages ./bv-pages --include-closed --title "My Project"

# Preview existing bundle
bv --preview-pages ./bv-pages

# Update existing deployment
bv --update-pages ./bv-pages
```

## Security Considerations
- No secrets in exports (bv data is typically non-sensitive)
- CSP headers for XSS prevention
- DOMPurify + Trusted Types for markdown rendering
- COOP/COEP via service worker for OPFS support
- Safety checks before any destructive git operations
- Permission prompts before software installation

## Future Enhancements (Out of Scope for MVP)
- Historical trend charts (requires multiple snapshots)
- Embedded search highlighting
- PDF export option
- Custom themes/branding

## Success Criteria
1. User can run `bv --pages` and have a live GitHub Pages site in <5 minutes
2. Site shows all data from bv TUI in readable format
3. Site works offline after initial load (OPFS caching)
4. Works on mobile browsers
5. Dark mode support
6. Full-text search works with ranking
7. Dependency graph is interactive and useful

## Architecture Rationale (Why SQLite, not JSON)
1. **Real Search**: FTS5 provides full-text search with ranking (bm25), snippets, prefix matching
2. **Complex Queries**: SQL handles dependency traversal, filtering, sorting without JavaScript complexity
3. **Scale**: Same approach works for 50 or 50,000 issues
4. **Performance**: Client queries only what it needs, pagination via LIMIT/OFFSET
5. **Caching**: OPFS support for offline use with cache invalidation
6. **Proven**: mcp_agent_mail demonstrates this architecture works exceptionally well

## References
- mcp_agent_mail share.py (2207 lines): Data export pipeline
- mcp_agent_mail share_to_github_pages.py (1353 lines): Deployment wizard
- mcp_agent_mail viewer_assets/: SPA implementation with sql.js

title: Support BEADS_DIR Environment Variable for Custom Directory Location
description:
## Feature Request

Allow users to specify a custom beads directory location via the BEADS_DIR environment variable. When set, it overrides the default `.beads` directory lookup.

## Use Cases

1. **Monorepos**: Single beads directory shared across multiple packages
2. **Non-standard layouts**: Projects where `.beads` isn't in the working directory
3. **Testing**: Point to test fixtures without changing directory
4. **Cross-directory access**: View beads from anywhere on the filesystem

## User Request

Suggested by @burke in GitHub PR #15:
> Allow users to specify a custom beads directory location via the BEADS_DIR environment variable. When set, it overrides the default .beads directory lookup. This enables more flexible project layouts and cross-directory beads file access.

## Proposed Implementation

### New function in loader.go

```go
// GetBeadsDir returns the beads directory path, respecting BEADS_DIR env var.
// If BEADS_DIR is set, it is used directly.
// Otherwise, falls back to .beads in the given repoPath (or cwd if empty).
func GetBeadsDir(repoPath string) (string, error) {
    // Check BEADS_DIR environment variable first
    if envDir := os.Getenv("BEADS_DIR"); envDir != "" {
        return envDir, nil
    }

    // Fall back to .beads in repo path
    if repoPath == "" {
        var err error
        repoPath, err = os.Getwd()
        if err != nil {
            return "", fmt.Errorf("failed to get cwd: %w", err)
        }
    }

    return filepath.Join(repoPath, ".beads"), nil
}
```

### Update LoadIssues to use GetBeadsDir

```go
func LoadIssues(repoPath string) ([]model.Issue, error) {
    beadsDir, err := GetBeadsDir(repoPath)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    // ... rest of function
}
```

### Update main.go for beadsPath

```go
// Get beads file path for live reload (respects BEADS_DIR)
beadsDir, _ := loader.GetBeadsDir("")
beadsPath, _ = loader.FindJSONLPath(beadsDir)
```

## Design Considerations

1. **Precedence**: BEADS_DIR should always win when set (explicit user intent)
2. **Validation**: Should we validate the directory exists? Or let it fail naturally?
3. **CLI flag alternative**: Could also add `--beads-dir` flag for one-off use
4. **Documentation**: Add to README and help output

## Priority Justification

P3 (Low) because:
- Not a bug, purely enhancement
- Workarounds exist (cd to directory, symlinks)
- Useful for power users but not essential
- Should wait until data loading bugs (bv-mvvu) are fixed first

## Dependencies

**Blocked by:** bv-mvvu (Data Integrity: Merge Artifact Files)
- Should implement after file selection logic is corrected
- Both touch loader.go and file resolution

## Test Plan

1. Test: BEADS_DIR set - uses that directory
2. Test: BEADS_DIR overrides repoPath parameter
3. Test: BEADS_DIR unset - falls back to .beads in cwd
4. Test: BEADS_DIR points to non-existent dir - appropriate error

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] BEADS_DIR environment variable respected
- [ ] Overrides default .beads directory lookup
- [ ] Error handling for invalid directories
- [ ] Tests cover all scenarios
- [ ] Documentation updated

## References

- GitHub PR #15: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/beads_viewer/pull/15
- Related: bv-mvvu (should be fixed first)
